                                January 15, 2015

NDSU Offers Health Insurance Workbook

BYLINE: The Oakes Times staff

LENGTH: 277  words


The North Dakota State University Extension Service has a helpful Smart Choice
Health Insurance Workbook available to assist consumers as they make important
health insurance plan choices.

"Many consumers may be uncomfortable or feel overwhelmed when it comes to making
decisions about health insurance coverage," says Lori Scharmer, NDSU Extension
Service family economics specialist.

"The workbook is designed to help consumers
make the best choice for their unique situations."

The workbook is available at http://www.ag.ndsu.edu/money.

The annual opportunity for uninsured individuals to enroll in private insurance
coverage and sign up for premium tax credits and cost sharing subsidies is now
through Feb. 15, 2015.

This also is the time that those people who were newly
insured in 2014 can renew their health plan coverage and subsidies.

An increasing number of North Dakotans are expected to enroll or renew policies
in health insurance plans during this open enrollment period.

"However, there are a few key dates consumers should be aware of when planning
their health insurance purchases for next year," Scharmer says.

Under the Affordable Care Act, uninsured individuals generally may enroll in
private, non group coverage plans or change plans only during open enrollment.

Jan. 1, 2015, is the earliest coverage can begin for a plan bought during the
open enrollment period.

People with qualifying events, such as getting married or having a baby, can
enroll in a health insurance plan at any time.

Consumers may purchase a qualifying health insurance plan through the federal
marketplace at http://www.healthcare.gov or through an insurance company or
agent.

Copyright 2015 Oakes Times


                              109 of 999 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                            April 13, 2017 Thursday

Health Insurance Plans 'Too Complicated to Understand'

LENGTH: 1023  words

DATELINE: New York



Hartford:  Central Connecticut State University has issued the following press
release:
A new survey by experts at the Health Disparities Institute of UConn Health
shows that many patients across Connecticut are struggling to understand their
complex, jargon-filled private health insurance plans and even to use their plan
benefits correctly.

Citing large differences in "health insurance literacy," the study shows that
people of color and those from ethnic minorities in particular have greater
difficulty accessing medical care and avoiding administrative hassles.

They are
also at greater risk of having delays in care, denials of coverage, and
receiving unexpected costly medical bills.

The researchers say today's complex insurance plans, with intricate cost
calculations and complicated language and terminology, can be very difficult to
understand, even for people with a college education.

Having health insurance is an invaluable asset, but what good is it if
people can't understand how to use it?

-- Victor Villagra
Since the enactment of the Affordable Care Act seven years ago, thousands of
Connecticut residents have enrolled in private health insurance plans through
the state's health insurance exchange Access Health CT. More people now have
access to essential health benefits through their plan, including inpatient
hospital care, mental health, prescription medication, and pregnancy and
childbirth care.

Thanks to the Affordable Care Act, people also have the right
to get the most important preventive care services completely free, with no
out-of-pocket cost.

However, the exchange reports that many enrollees are not
using or fully taking advantage of those services, and that many still do not
have a primary care doctor.

These observations of low plan use; news reports of surprise medical bills; the
fact that medical bills are the number one cause of personal bankruptcy; and
other difficulties in accessing health care, spurred the Health Disparities
Institute to study health insurance literacy rates, to see how to help more
patients use their benefits to achieve good health.

Staff at the Institute say
that recent consumer protection legislation is a good first step.

The Health Disparities Institute team is calling for a coordinated statewide
effort in collaboration with health insurance providers to simplify health
insurance plans and their language, and to begin an aggressive educational
awareness campaign to increase literacy.

The goal is to enhance patients' access
to the healthcare services covered under their plans, while avoiding the burden
of unnecessary costs.

"Having health insurance is an invaluable asset, but what good is it if people
can't understand how to use it?"

asks Dr. Victor Villagra, associate director of
the Health Disparities Institute at UConn Health.

"First, we need to start raising health insurance literacy to remove an
important source of health disparity," he says, "but a more permanent solution
would be removing complex language and convoluted rules from health insurance.

Access to simpler, more consumer-friendly insurance plans should be a priority
in order to achieve greater health equity for Connecticut citizens."

The team also recommends the use of trained, in-person health insurance
navigators or coaches to help guide patients.

The good news is that we now have the opportunity to seize the moment in
Connecticut ... to simplify and improve health insurance understanding for all
people.

-- Judith Fifield
The poll, conducted by phone during 2016, measured health insurance literacy
among 516 adult Connecticut residents enrolled in a qualified health plan
through Access Health CT, the state health insurance exchange.

The results
showed that this population struggled to understand basic health insurance
terminology, such as "premium," "deductible," and "co-pay," and how to use their
benefits.

The researchers report that those with lower educational levels, who
are black, Hispanic, or don't speak English as their first language, have a
greater challenge understanding and using their health insurance compared to
their white counterparts.

"Health insurance literacy is a health care disparity that we actually have the
power to do something about, and we can continue to measure our progress," says
Dr. Judith Fifield, director of the Health Disparities Institute.

"The first big
step is stepping-up our patient education to increase health insurance literacy,
and also to implement more consumer-friendly health insurance plans."

Key Connecticut Health Insurance Literacy Survey Findings
    Only 8 out of 13 questions (62 percent) regarding basic health insurance
were answered correctly;
     1 in 5 (20 percent) respondents did not understand the use of the insurance
word "premium;"
     2 out of 3 (66 percent) did not understand the word "formulary;"
     Only 1 in 3 (33 percent) could calculate their "out-of-pocket" cost of a
hospital bill when a "deductible" and a "copay" were part of the insurance
benefit;
     Only 4 out of 10 (40 percent) knew that "in-network hospitals do not always
have in-network doctors."

Fifield says that until now, there has been no information about the health
insurance literacy rates of Connecticut citizens enrolled in private health
insurance plans.

"While these baseline survey results overall are not much different from the
rest of the country, the survey uncovered a terrible inequity that puts people
of color at a great disadvantage," she says.

"The good news is that we now have
the opportunity to seize the moment in Connecticut - especially during this time
of healthcare reform debates - to simplify and improve health insurance
understanding for all people."

Additional Health Disparities Institute contributors to the survey project
include Emil Coman, Bhumika Parikh, Denise O. Smith, and Jeanette Goyzueta.

Collaborators include Access Health Connecticut and Acturus.

Funding for the
project came from the Connecticut Health Foundation.

In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

LOAD-DATE: April 13, 2017

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire

                              110 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                              The Maryland Gazette

                           February 10, 2007 Saturday

GOOD QUESTION

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg.

A7

LENGTH: 478  words


Where can I find information on buying a health insurance plan if I don't have
one with my employer?

Because health insurance is administered differently in each state, a good
starting place to find more information is the health or insurance department
for the state where you live.

Some states offer programs to the uninsured, such
as the Family Health Plus program in New York state, allowing individuals or
families with limited income to purchase their own plan.

Alternatively,
individual or family plans are offered at market rates through a number of
national and regional carriers.

Those looking for individual and family plans can also start their research at
Web sites such as www.healthdecisions.org and www.healthinsuranceinfo.net.

Those who buy health insurance on their own tend to be relatively price
sensitive since they absorb the entire cost of the plan themselves.

Premiums
vary by state and risk profile.

A 2004 survey by the trade group America's
Health Insurance Plans shows that individual annual premiums ranged from $1,885
in California to $6,048 in New Jersey.

Ninety-four percent of the individual
policies sold were on average less than $3,000.

Nationwide, the survey showed
annual premiums on average were $2,268 for individuals and $4,424 for families.

One New York-based nonprofit, the Freelancers Union, addresses a growing need
for plans not sponsored by a company and has plans to expand its services to
members outside New York.

Members around the country can buy disability and life insurance, but only those
in New York can buy health insurance.

In the coming months, Freelancers Union
plans to begin offering options to buy health insurance in the states with the
greatest demand.

The nonprofit's largest membership can be found in New Jersey, California,
Connecticut, Pennsylvania, Florida, Massachusetts, Texas, Ohio, Illinois and
Maryland.

Other organizations that offer health insurance options include
AllFreelance.com, the National Association for the Self-Employed, the National
Writers Union and others.

Change is coming that may affect how not only freelance workers, but full-time
employees, buy health insurance.

Freelancers Union founder Sara Horowitz said the rising cost of health insurance
is contributing to the decline of the employer-sponsored system for health care.

She predicts that a growing number of individuals will begin buying their own
plans, leading to a "quintessential David and Goliath" problem where consumers
have no buying power and no ombudsman to help them navigate their medical
claims.

That, Ms. Horowitz said, will lead to a reinvention of how we buy health
insurance, with people grouping themselves together to increase their
negotiating power and fund health advocates who help negotiate the claims
process.

"I think we're going to see a rise in these services over time," she said.

B3

LENGTH: 478  words


Where can I find information on buying a health insurance plan if I don't have
one with my employer?

Because health insurance is administered differently in each state, a good
starting place to find more information is the health or insurance department
for the state where you live.

Some states offer programs to the uninsured, such
as the Family Health Plus program in New York state, allowing individuals or
families with limited income to purchase their own plan.

Alternatively,
individual or family plans are offered at market rates through a number of
national and regional carriers.

Those looking for individual and family plans can also start their research at
Web sites such as www.healthdecisions.org and www.healthinsuranceinfo.net.

Those who buy health insurance on their own tend to be relatively price
sensitive since they absorb the entire cost of the plan themselves.

Premiums
vary by state and risk profile.

A 2004 survey by the trade group America's
Health Insurance Plans shows that individual annual premiums ranged from $1,885
in California to $6,048 in New Jersey.

Ninety-four percent of the individual
policies sold were on average less than $3,000.

Nationwide, the survey showed
annual premiums on average were $2,268 for individuals and $4,424 for families.

for plans not sponsored by a company and has plans to expand its services to
members outside New York.

months, Freelancers Union plans to begin offering options to buy health
insurance in the states with the greatest demand.

Connecticut, Pennsylvania, Florida, Massachusetts, Texas, Ohio, Illinois and

Writers Union and others.

claims.

That, Ms. Horowitz said, will lead to a reinvention of how we buy health
insurance, with people grouping themselves together to increase their
negotiating power and fund health advocates who help negotiate the claims
process.

"I think we're going to see a rise in these services over time," she said.

- Associated Press

                              112 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                     Charleston Daily Mail (West Virginia)

                          November 13, 2013, Wednesday

AFFORDABLE CARE ACT;
Plans canceled for 8,800;
in state;
Number of West;
Virginians losing current coverage relatively small compared to US data

BYLINE: ZACK HAROLD, DAILY MAIL CAPITOL REPORTER

SECTION: NEWS; Pg.

P1A

LENGTH: 540 words


About 8,800 West Virginia residents stand to lose their health insurance because
of the Affordable Care Act's new requirements for insurance plans.

The health care reform law, passed in 2010, requires U.S. citizens to enroll in
health insurance but also includes a list of requirements for health insurance
plans.

Insurance providers must cancel or change plans that don't meet those
requirements.

Policyholders are eligible for new plans through the government's
health insurance marketplace, although that website has suffered crippling
technical problems since its launch last month.

Policy cancellations largely affect individuals who purchase their own health
insurance plans.

According to the West Virginia Center on Budget and Policy, the state Offices of
the Insurance Commissioner have received about 8,800 discontin- uation notices
for individual insurance plans.

Most of those people - about 8,600 - are insured through Highmark West Virginia.

President Obama, in his attempts to sell the Affordable Care Act to the American
public and lawmakers, frequently insisted people who liked their current health
care plans could keep them.

That has proved not to be true, and a recent NBC News investigation found the
Obama administration knew it would not be the case as early as 2010.

It's unclear how many people could lose their current health insurance plans
because of the rules changes.

The number of West Virginians losing their current health care plans is
relatively small.

While 8,800 are facing discontinuation of their policies, about 25,000 state
residents had individual health insurance plans in 2011, according to the latest
available data collated by the nonprofit Kaiser Family Foundation.

Most West Virginians, about 910,000, receive health insurance through their
employers, according to an actuarial study commissioned by the state earlier
this year.

About 183,000 received insurance through Medicaid and the Children's Health
Insurance Program, and 246,000 were uninsured.

Those numbers did not include Medicare-eligible individuals.

According to census
data, about 307,000 state residents received health insurance through Medicare
in 2011.

The National Republican Senatorial Committee sent out a press release Tuesday
attempting to tie the Affordable Care Act to Secretary of State Natalie Tennant,
who is running as a Democrat for U.S. Senate.

The NRSC claimed 147,000 West Virginia residents "are at risk of losing their
health insurance," but Brandon Merritt, health care analyst for the West
Virginia Center on Budget and Policy, said that figure is far above any
estimates he's seen.

"Currently we have about 28,000 in our individual market.

That's not even within
the margin of error," he said.

Follow
him at www.twitter.com/ZackHarold.

LOAD-DATE: November 13, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                      Copyright 2013 Charleston Newspapers


                              113 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                        The Jamestown Sun (North Dakota)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                          September 26, 2013 Thursday

Affordable Care Act: Citizens may start enrolling Tuesday in their state's
health insurance marketplace

BYLINE: Chris Olson, The Jamestown Sun, N.D.

SECTION: LIFESTYLE

LENGTH: 798 words


Sept. 26--Americans have been hearing about the Affordable Care Act since before
it was signed into law by President Barack Obama on March 23, 2010.

On Tuesday, citizens may start enrolling in their state's health insurance
marketplace by going to www.healthcare.gov online.

According to the healthcare.gov website, which is run by the U.S. Department of
Health and Human Services, the ACA is a law that puts into place comprehensive
health insurance reforms that were to be rolled out over four years starting in
2010.

Mike Potts, Blue Cross and Blue Shield of North Dakota's director of employer
consulting and wellness, said more specifically the law requires that all
Americans purchase health insurance.

"There are changes in insurance regulations so that all people are covered,
including those with pre-existing conditions," Potts said.

The ACA offers many different options for people seeking health insurance,
according to Potts.

Those options are explained in a different story in this
series.

For employers the ACA offers options for providing health insurance to
employees, Potts said.

Early in the process of getting the ACA approved by Congress, Obama promised
that people who have health insurance provided by their employers would be able
to keep that coverage if they like it.

"Essentially those health plans were 'grandfathered' in.

If an employer had a
health insurance plan for his employees before the ACA was signed, you could
keep it," he said.

Potts said about 75 percent of BCBSND's employer groups decided to keep their
grandfathered-in health insurance plans.

"They found their employees like their health plans and want to keep them,"
Potts said.

For employers that didn't get their health insurance plans grandfathered, Potts
said those companies may find less-expensive plans through the health insurance
marketplace.

The cost-saving comes from an ACA requirement that the most
expensive rate for a single-payer plan can't be more than three-times the rate
for the least expensive single-payer plan, Potts said.

For employers with 50 or more full-time-equivalent employees the ACA will
require those companies to provide health insurance to those full-time employees
starting in January 2015.

A full-time-equivalent employee is defined in the ACA
as someone who works 30 hours a week or more.

"If they (larger employers) don't offer coverage, those businesses will be
assessed a $2,000 per year fine (per employee), with a break given on the first
30 employees," Potts said.

Potts said any health insurance coverage an employer offers must meet the
minimum coverage requirement of covering 60 percent of total costs for medical
services.

The coverage must be affordable as well, meaning the cost for the
employee only -- not including extra costs for insuring other family members
under the plan -- can't exceed 9.5 percent of the employee's wages or income.

Paul Witthauer, owner and agent of Witthauer Investment and Insurance Services,
said health insurance agents and brokers like him have been worrying about what
the ACA will mean for their business and clients.

"The good news for us is we will be playing an important role in registering
people, helping them enroll in health insurance plans under the ACA," he said.

Witthauer said he has been through training sessions sponsored by the federal
government for insurance agents to learn how to help people enroll for coverage
through the healthcare.gov website.

North Dakota opted not to establish its own
health insurance marketplace.

This means North Dakota Residents who want to
enroll in a health care plan must do so through the federal government.

Witthauer said he is glad that so far health insurance agents are being included
in the ACA process.

I have been inundated with calls from my
clients wanting to know what they should be doing.

The frustrating part has been
not having ready answers because the information simply wasn't out there for
agents to easily access," he said.

Witthauer said he was not a supporter of enacting the ACA, but knows it's the
law and everyone has to work with it.

"I have concerns about the ACA, but it's more the unknowns for me.

There are
good parts, it will be helpful getting health insurance to people who currently
don't have it, and that is a good thing," he said.

For more information about the ACA go to www.bcbsnd.com or healthcare.gov.

Who needs the marketplace and what are the choices in the
marketplace?

Sun reporter Chris Olson can be reached at 701-952-8454 or by email at
colson@jamestownsun.com

___ (c)2013 The Jamestown Sun (Jamestown, N.D.) Visit The Jamestown Sun
(Jamestown, N.D.) at www.jamestownsun.com Distributed by MCT Information
Services

                              114 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                              India Insurance News

                      July 12, 2017 Wednesday 6:30 AM EST

AgileHealthInsurance.com Expands its Leading Marketplace of Affordable Health
Insurance Options

LENGTH: 747  words


July 12 -- AgileHealthInsurance.com announced today it has launched a new
portfolio of health insurance products called "health benefit insurance plans."

Health benefit insurance plans are specially designed to help consumers who are
at risk for going underinsured or uninsured, in the absence of low-cost health
plans.

Many of the new health benefit insurance plans are priced under $100 a
month, a key price ceiling within the American health insurance market.

Unlike major medical plans, such as Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) insurance
plans or short-term health insurance plans, health benefit insurance plans pay a
set amount of money when the enrollee experiences covered medical events.

Payment amounts vary depending on the specific medical event, with more
expensive medical services typically receiving higher payments than those for
less costly events.

Depending on the health insurance benefit plan, this money
is paid directly to the enrollee to offset out-of-pocket costs or lost income,
or it is paid directly to the enrollee's health care provider.

Most health
benefit insurance plans offered on AgileHealthInsurace.com are not medically
underwritten, but they will not cover pre-existing conditions.

This means that a
consumer can apply without worry that the application will be rejected due to a
current health condition, but the plan will only pay for covered medical events
that occur after the application date.

Applications can be made any time of
year, and coverage can begin in as little as one day after purchase.

Plans can
be paid for by consumers on a month-to-month basis and cancelled by the consumer
at any time without restriction.

Additionally, consumers can keep their health
benefit plan until they are Medicare eligible at age 65, and in some cases
longer.

"The reality of today's health insurance market is that we have a growing
segment of Americans who are locked out of Obamacare insurance plans due to high
premiums, ineligibility for government premium subsidies, lack of insurance
company participation or open enrollment restrictions," said Bruce Telkamp,
founder and CEO of AgileHealthInsurance.com.

"Our mission has been to pioneer a
scalable Internet platform to help these consumers find and purchase lower-cost
health insurance options that meet their unique needs.

We are very excited to be
complementing our market-leading short-term offering with a new online portfolio
of health benefit insurance plans.

We believe that the health benefit plan
category has the potential to become an important segment of the individual
health insurance marketplace."

AgileHealthInsurance.com offers health benefit insurance plans that provide
payments to help with four categories of medical expenses:

* Doctor office visits coverage: pays for a predetermined number of visits to a
doctor's office, as well as associated lab work

* Hospital visits coverage: pays for hospital admission due to illness or injury

* Accident coverage: pays when accidents result in an injury, such as a broken
leg or torn knee

* Critical illnesses coverage: pays in the event of a serious illness, such as a
heart attack or cancer

Many of the health benefit insurance plans offered at AgileHealthInsurance.com
have additional benefits such as a telemedicine service that provides 24/7
access to a doctor or nurse for basic medical consults and advisory services to
help consumers navigate the health care system.

All of the health benefit
insurance plans offered on AgileHealthInsurance.com have top ratings from AM
Best, ranging from B++ (Good) to A+ (Superior) in financial strength.

AgileHealthInsurance.com intends to continue investment and innovation within
the health insurance market, including expanding its health benefit plan
offerings throughout 2017.

AgileHealthInsurance.com was created to educate people about the benefits of
short-term health insurance and other affordable health insurance products.

AgileHealthInsurance provides a fast, online process for purchasing these health
plans.

Short-term health insurance is a flexible and low-cost major medical
insurance for individuals without expensive pre-existing health conditions.

It
is not Obamacare.

Short-term health plans offer consumers the flexibility to
choose health plans with the benefits that matter most to them and combine these
benefits with broad provider networks.

Additional information about
AgileHealthInsurance can be found at www.AgileHealthInsurance.com.

Source: AgileHealthInsurance.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Web Publication

                              115 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                     The Capital Times (Madison, Wisconsin)

                          September 2, 2009 Wednesday
                                  ALL EDITION

PAUL RYAN'S HEALTH CARE PLAN IS A DANGEROUS

BYLINE: ROBERT KRAIG

SECTION: OPINION; GUEST COLUMN; Pg.

WEB

LENGTH: 791 words


Rx Lost in the passionate debate on President Obama's health care reform
initiative is that Congressman Paul Ryan, R-Janesville, has introduced his own
plan.

Unfortunately, Ryan's plan would make the health care crisis even worse by
shifting more power away from patients and to the health insurance industry.

Most agree that skyrocketing health care costs are economically unsustainable.

According to a report co-released by the New America Foundation and Citizen
Action of Wisconsin, a family health insurance policy in Wisconsin will cost
nearly $25,000 a year by 2016 absent fundamental reform.

Ryan's plan, H.R.

2520 (co-sponsored with Sen. Tom Coburn of Oklahoma), would
give insurance companies even more latitude to discriminate based on age, health
status, gender, and pre-existing conditions, and to profit from selling policies
with gaping holes that leave consumers vulnerable to claim and treatment
denials.

The first key feature of Ryan's plan, like the proposal John McCain advocated
during the 2008 campaign, is to tax health insurance benefits.

This is a radical
departure from the policy of the United States since World War II of using the
tax code to encourage employers to provide health insurance to their workers.

The policy of not taxing health insurance benefits has worked so well that over
two-thirds of Wisconsinites under the 65 get their health insurance at work.

A report from the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities concludes that Ryan's
plan would cause millions of Americans to lose their employer-based health
insurance.

The Economic Policy Institute estimates that 415,000 Wisconsinites
would lose their health insurance at work if those benefits were taxed.

The second key feature of Ryan's plan, as it clearly anticipates that many would
lose their health insurance at work if benefits are taxed, is to provide tax
credits of $2,290 for individuals and $5,710 for families to help them buy
insurance on their own.

These amounts are grossly inadequate except for the
youngest and healthiest.

The average cost for group health insurance in
Wisconsin is now $13,559 for family coverage and $4,916 for individual coverage.

Even worse, by forcing millions of people who now get their health insurance at
work to buy it directly, Ryan's plan would give the insurance industry greater
power to skim off the most profitable and healthy individuals, and to charge
discriminatory rates to everyone else for bare bones policies that expose them
to potentially bankrupting costs and treatment denials when they most need
medical care.

Ryan asserts that his plan would limit insurance industry abuses, but the
consumer protections in the bill are full of holes.

Like Obama and the House
Democrats, Ryan proposes that health insurance exchanges be created where
consumers can shop for insurance.

Ryan
leaves the creation of such exchanges to the voluntary action of each state.

Worse, Ryan's plan would actually prohibit the new health insurance exchanges
from limiting premiums, co-pays, deductibles, and out-of-pocket expenses.

Insurance companies would be free to price anyone out of the market that they
consider a bad risk.

Ryan's bill also has no meaningful coverage standards, so insurance companies
could continue to sell policies filled with dangerous coverage gaps.

Ryan's health care plan also would eliminate Medicaid coverage for low-income
seniors, which helps them afford Medicare and services such as home health care.

In addition, it would force low-income families on Medicaid to go out and buy
health insurance on the private insurance market.

Henry Aaron of the Brookings
Institution, one of the top health care experts in the nation, concludes that
"the idea of turning Medicaid patients over to private insurance is whacky."

The whole thrust of Ryan's health insurance plan is to give the health insurance
industry more power to decide how much to charge, what medical services would be
covered, and what co-pays, deductibles, and benefit caps would apply.

The
deciding factor in all of these decisions would be profits, not the health care
needs of most Americans.

It is no surprise that according to the Center for Responsive Politics, Ryan's
largest political contributor is the health insurance industry, which has given
him $493,000.

It is fair to ask: Is Paul Ryan representing the people of
southern Wisconsin or the health insurance industry?

Robert Kraig is the program director for Citizen Action of Wisconsin, a
grass-roots organization with 90,000 members across the state which advocates
for health care reform.

Posted in Guest on Wednesday, September 2, 2009 5:00 am Updated: 7:22 am.

Paul
Ryan, Citizen Action Of Wisconsin, New America Foundation, Health Care

LOAD-DATE: September 5, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Column

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                    Copyright 2009 Madison Newspapers, Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved


                              116 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                           The Edmond Sun (Oklahoma)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            August 30, 2008 Saturday

Health insurance hope: State efforts offer solutions for individuals who lack
health insurance

BYLINE: Mark Schlachtenhaufen, The Edmond Sun, Okla.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 758 words


Aug. 30--EDMOND -- Until recently, at times Terry Fisher went without health
insurance because of the high cost.

Fisher, shop manager at Edmond's W & W Tire, said due to the high costs of
health insurance occasionally he would forgo seeing a doctor.

Insurance Commissioner Kim Holland, head of the Oklahoma Insurance Department,
said nearly 700,000 Oklahomans do not have health insurance.

Holland said in
recent years the number of uninsured Oklahomans has been rising, as have the
costs of both health care and health insurance.

Holland estimates the cost of health insurance is increased by as much as 25
percent to cover health-care services provided to individuals without coverage.

Holland said the cost-shift creates a vicious cycle of increasing premiums
causing more people to drop coverage.

The high cost of health insurance has varied social and economic consequences,
Holland said.

"I think it is one of the most significant, dramatic social situations Oklahoma
has to deal with now and in the future," Holland said.

National surveys show that the primary reason people are uninsured is the high
cost of insurance coverage.

Premiums for employer-based health insurance rose by
6.1 percent in 2007, according to the National Coalition on Health Care.

Premiums for small employers, on average, increased 5.5 percent and firms with
less than 24 workers experienced an increase of 6.8 percent.

According to the Kaiser Family Foundation and the Health Research and
Educational Trust, premiums for employer-sponsored health insurance have been
rising four times faster on average than workers' earnings since 2000.

For the most part, the federal government has left health care up to individual
states.

In Oklahoma, HCR 1010, authored by Rep. Ron Peterson, R-Tulsa, and Sen.
Susan Paddack, D-Ada, empowered a Core Benefit Task Force to make
recommendations to the Legislature for the creation of a lower-cost, basic
health insurance plan.

Last summer, Holland announced the launch of a statewide series of community
meetings for the purpose of receiving input from Oklahomans about what services
should be covered under such a plan.

In the coming months, work on the state plan will continue.

Meanwhile, an
existing state program offers hope for small businesses.

The Insure Oklahoma/O-EPIC employer-sponsored insurance program pays part of the
health plan premiums for eligible employees working for businesses with 50 or
fewer full-time employees.

Legislation passed in 2004 authorized the Oklahoma Health Care Authority to
develop a program assisting adults age 19-64 who do not exceed 185 percent of
the federal poverty level with either a portion of their private health plan
premiums or the purchase of a state-sponsored health plan operated under the
state Medicaid program.

Holland said a good resource for information about health insurance is the
Insurance Department's Web site, www.ok.gov/oid/.

The site contains information
on options for the uninsured, private health insurance, insurance for high-risk
individuals and income-based health insurance programs.

Jana Kappel, office manager for W & W Tire, said worries about not having health
insurance prompted her to begin investigating health insurance plans for the
family owned and operated business.

Kappel said when she got quotes on the state plan from a local insurance agent,
she couldn't believe what she was hearing.

Terry Fisher said he got on the state plan in February 2007.

Fisher said he pays
part of the premium and the company and the state also pay part of the costs.

"It's an ideal plan," Fisher said.

"It makes the rising costs of health care
more affordable.

If Fisher, his wife or their four children need to visit their medical clinic,
they have a $25 co-payment.

Kappel said without the state plan she probably would not have insurance.

Recently losing a relative to cancer made it even more important, she said.

NEXT WEEK'S TOPIC: How to get a raise.

http://www.edmondsun.com/.

to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                              117 of 999 DOCUMENTS



                              Sunday Business Post

                                 March 1, 2015

Insurers carving up health market

SECTION: PERSONAL FINANCE

LENGTH: 1215 words


Health insurers are hoping for an influx of younger customers in the coming
weeks, ahead of new rules that will penalise those who delay entering the health
insurance market until they are older.

The health insurance market will be shaken up by the government's new lifetime
community rating system later this year, with the new plan designed to bring
younger customers back into the health insurance market in a bid to re-balance
the demographics of the market and stabilise the cost of private health
insurance.

From May 1, higher charges will apply to people who are 35 years or more when
they first take out health insurance.

Someone over 35 who takes out health
insurance for the first time after May will face a loading of 2 per cent per
year.

With just two months to go before the new rules kick in, insurers are preparing
for a flurry of activity in the coming weeks - and experts warn that consumers
who don't sign up for health insurance before the April 30 deadline could find
themselves permanently priced out of the market.

As the details of the government's lifetime community rating plan emerged,
health insurance analysts predicted that insurers would launch new plans before
May geared towards people under 35.

These predictions proved correct with all
health insurers bringing new plans to market in recent weeks, designed to appeal
to younger customers.

More plans could follow ahead of the new rules, but
insurers must give 30 days' notice to the Health Insurance Authority (HIA), the
regulator for the private health insurance market, ahead of launching a new plan
.

These new plans - dubbed 'value pack' by some analysts - are considerably
cheaper than the other products on the market, but it's a case of you get what
you pay for, say market experts.

Insurers are stripping out all they can to make products as cheap as they can,
Dermot Goode, a health cover analyst at Total Health Cover, said.

These plans
give you very little.

They are a way to avoid the loading, but they do not
provide comprehensive cover.

Prices for the new wave of plans start from EUR 409 for Glo's latest offering,
rising to EUR 425 for Aviva's new low-cost plan.

VHI's latest plan costs EUR 449
per adult, while Laya recently announced a EUR 430 health insurance plan.

In Goode's view, the latest range of plans to emerge from health insurers are
like riding a scooter when you want to drive a car  .

Anne Frawley, head of healthcare consulting at Mercer, described the latest
batch of plans from health insurers as    plans that tick a box  .

She said that
people who sign up for these products would escape the loading, but stressed
that they would have    very basic cover  .

**Battle lines drawn**

Insurers are hopeful that the new rules could drive some of those who left the
health insurance market in recent years to return, and may also encourage new
customers to enter the market for the first time.

There's a big pool of
potential customers to play for, with figures from the Health Insurance
Authority showing that almost 300,000 people have left the market since its peak
at the end of 2008, when almost 2.3 million people were insured.

Even at the
market's peak, only about 53 per cent of the population had health insurance.

According to Goode, there's a    land grab   going on between insurers.

They
know there are tens of thousands of potential customers to play for in the
coming weeks, and insurance companies want to win as many of these as possible,
he said.

It's an opportunity to get the phones hopping.

I'd expect that insurers will try
to upsell people other, more expensive plans,   Goode said.

Frawley agreed, saying that insurers were keen    to just get people in  .

Nearly 300,000 people left the market - and on top of that there's probably a
certain number of people who just will never take it [health insurance] out,
she said.

**A lot of work to do**

Research published by health insurer Laya last week indicated that the
government, the Health Insurance Authority and insurers have an uphill battle on
their hands in the coming weeks, with little awareness of the new rules.

According to Laya's statistics, just one in five Irish people over 30 have heard
of lifetime community rating and just 4 per cent say they understand the new
system.

The Health Insurance Authority is gearing up to launch a public awareness
campaign later this month as the new rules loom for health insurance customers.

The HIA campaign, which is due to launch in the coming weeks, is likely to
extend across multiple channels and include print, television and online.

Insurance Ireland, the representative body for the insurance industry, is also
planning to run its own public awareness campaign ahead of the new rules.

It's not just a lack of awareness that insurers are up against.

Affordability
remains a big problem for many consumers, even with the new, lower cost options
on offer.

Laya's recent research found that 62 per cent of those currently without health
insurance do not plan to take out a policy before the April 30 deadline, with
affordability - or a lack of it - cited as the main barrier to purchasing health
insurance cover.

**Employers need to prepare too**

The new rules will not just affect consumers.

The impending deadline may also
pose difficulties for employers who offer health insurance to staff as a
benefit.

Goode said many employers are unaware of the impact of the new rules.

Corporate clients are only waking up to this now,   he said.

The big question for employers is who covers the additional cost for the loading
that may apply for those joining the company scheme, Frawley said.

Some employers may choose to pay a set amount towards health cover for their
employees, leaving employees to pay the difference.

However, in more competitive
industries, where attracting staff is a challenge and there's more pressure to
provide a bumper remuneration package to attract talent, employers may have
little choice but to pay the extra cost associated with the new loading.

Employers will closely watch their peers on this,   Goode said.

**The risks ahead**

Insurers are banking on adding younger customers in the coming weeks, but if
they don't there could be more problems ahead for the health insurance market.

The risk on these entry-level plans is that, if they don't get enough young
non-claiming customers in, they could take a hit,   Goode said.

But I expect
that they'll have a clever customer segmentation strategy here.

According to Frawley, the risk for insurers is relatively small, given the basic
benefits on offer from the new plans.

They are not that exposed given the
level of benefits,   she said.

However, Frawley said that if the expected influx of customers doesn't
materialise in the coming weeks, insurers could find themselves in familiar
territory: with an ageing customer base, increasing claims and significant price
pressure.

The next two months are crucial for the health insurance market, as there are
tens of thousands of people who could be left permanently unable to take out
health insurance if they miss this window, experts warn.

The impact of missing this deadline is hugely important,   Frawley said.

There will be people who, if they don't join now, could find themselves priced
out of the market.

                        Contra Costa Times (California)

                            August 7, 2013 Wednesday

Firms line up for California health insurance marketplace

BYLINE: From staff reports Contra Costa Times

SECTION: BREAKING; My Town; News; Local; Business

LENGTH: 322 words


Twelve insurance companies have signed contracts to join the state's newly
created health benefit exchange, the Covered California agency announced
Wednesday.

The state exchange, a consumer health insurance marketplace set up under the
national health care reform act, will open for business in January.

It will
permit consumers to easily comparison shop for health insurance available at
variety of costs and coverage levels.

The health insurance companies will offer coverage in the individual exchange
and six of them will offer plans through the exchange's Small Business Health
Options Program market.

"Covered California and the insurance companies participating in our marketplace
have worked hard to secure these contracts, which will mean affordable health
insurance plans for millions of people who currently have no coverage or whose
coverage is too expensive," said Covered California Executive Director Peter V.
Lee, in a news release.

The following companies will offer plans in Covered California's individual
market:

-- Alameda Alliance for Health

-- Anthem Blue Cross of California

-- Blue Shield of California

-- Chinese Community Health Plan

-- Contra Costa Health Plan

-- Health Net

-- Kaiser Permanente

-- L.A. Care Health Plan

-- Molina Healthcare

-- Sharp Health Plan

-- Valley Health Plan

-- Western Health Advantage

Covered California selected the following health plans to participate in small
business program:

-- Blue Shield of California

-- Chinese Community Health Plan

-- Health Net

-- Kaiser Permanente

-- Sharp Health Plan

-- Western Health Advantage

The signed contracts culminate months of competitive bidding and negotiations,
Covered California said.

Covered California is an independent agency of the state government whose job is
to operate the new market for California's consumers.

It is overseen by a
five-member board appointed by the Governor and the Legislature.

More information is available atwww.CoveredCA.com .

                              120 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                                THE KOREA HERALD

                          February 27, 2008 Wednesday

Life insurers bank on private health plans

LENGTH: 519 words


Local life insurers are set to venture into the lucrative private health
insurance sector, anticipating that the new administration of President Lee
Myung-bak will accelerate the deregulation of the financial industry.

Many investors expect that the insurance sector, along with the brokerage
industry, will be the biggest beneficiaries of the Lee administration's promise
to wage a sweeping deregulation campaign.

"There seems to be consensus that the new administration will advocate
developing the private health insurance market," said Park Sun-ho, an analyst
who covers the life insurance industry at Goodmorning Shinhan Securities Co.

Promoting the private health insurance market has been considered a way of
supplementing the national health insurance scheme which has been running
chronic deficits.

At present, non-life insurance companies have sold a limited
range of health insurance policies, along with their mainstay of accident
insurance and permanent health insurance policies.

Korea's rapid demographic
changes and the consumers' desire for quality medical services have prompted
policymakers to seek ways to complement the public health insurance plans.

The nation's major life insurance players, including Samsung Life Insurance,
Korea Life Insurance and Kyobo Life Insurance, are planning to introduce private
health plans soon, industry insiders say.

A Korea Life Insurance official said
yesterday that the company plans to start selling private health insurance plans
within the next four months.

Both Samsung and Kyobo said they are also working
to introduce private health insurance policies to cater to the rising local
demand for insurance policies which cover more sophisticated medical services.

Private health insurance policy holders can be fully reimbursed for the medical
expenses that are not covered by the public insurance program.

In Korea, the
National Health Insurance covers the entire population.

The compulsory social
insurance system is financed by contributions from the insured, along with
government subsidies.

"I believe that many issues have to be resolved before the private health
insurance services take off in Korea," said Lee Suk-ho, a research fellow at the
Korea Institute of Finance.

The full-fledged development of private health
insurance plans, without sufficient financial support from the public health
insurance scheme, could force insurance companies to raise their premiums, and
the price increase could eventually result in higher medical expenses, he
explained.

In order to spur the private health insurance market, it is necessary to
standardize insurance policies and build an infrastructure that will allow
insurance companies to share information about insurance policy holders,
industry insiders said.

"The information-sharing system is crucial to prevent
policy holders from buying multiple products in this market," said a Korea Life
Insurance official.

Wider coverage by private health plans could cause a "moral
hazard" by providing incentives for policy holders to claim unnecessary medical
expenses, he added.

By Kim Jung-min

(jungmin@heraldm.com)

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

LOAD-DATE: July 14, 2016


                              122 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                                   USA TODAY

                            January 13, 2009 Tuesday
                                 FINAL EDITION

Don't crowd out insurers;
Opposing view: Government plan would encourage employers to drop health
coverage.

10A

LENGTH: 413 words


"If you have (health) insurance you like, you keep that insurance,"
President-elect Barack Obama has assured Americans.

Unfortunately, that's not
what would happen under his proposed health reform plan.

In fact, millions would
lose their existing coverage.

A major component of Obama's plan is a national health insurance exchange, in
which the government competes with private insurance.

In theory, everyone wins
-- the competition lowers rates and induces insurers to offer better plans.

In
reality, the presence of a large national plan would, perversely enough,
encourage employers to drop coverage (which is, after all, quite expensive).

Let
the government take care of employees, they'd reason.

The inevitable result: a massive crowd-out of private coverage -- especially
employer-based coverage, which is how nine out of 10 Americans under 65 get
their insurance.

In an October analysis, the Lewin Group, a leading econometrics
firm, estimated that Obama's plan would dramatically alter the way in which many
Americans are covered: 21.6 million would lose their private coverage, and about
48.3 million would end up in public coverage through the new government health
plan, as well as the State Children's Health Insurance Program and Medicaid.

Lewin estimated that 18.6 million employees would find themselves in the new
government plan, as employers switched from private health insurance.

The end result of this enormous shift is all too predictable: a rapid evolution
toward a single-payer system of national health insurance.

At the very least,
we'd wind up with a highly regulated and painfully sluggish, centrally
controlled system in which private health plans and private medical practice are
private in name only.

Meanwhile, millions of Americans would lose their employer-based health
insurance.

And the artificially swollen and heavily subsidized government health
plan would remain as the benchmark for "private" decisions concerning financing,
benefits and standards within the new  health exchange.

The overwhelming majority of Americans who get health insurance through work say
they're satisfied with it.

And most American voters say they oppose any kind of
government-controlled plan if it means they'd have to change their own health
coverage.

Under Obama's plan, though, that's exactly what many would have to do.

Robert Moffit is director of the Center for Health Policy Studies at The
Heritage Foundation, a conservative think tank in Washington.

LOAD-DATE: January 13, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: DEBATE

PUBLICATION-TYPE: NEWSPAPER


                      Copyright 2009 Gannett Company, Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved


                              123 of 999 DOCUMENTS



                              Sunday Business Post

                                 March 15, 2015

Insured but not covered

SECTION: MARKETS

LENGTH: 1245 words


When Kevin Cumiskey was notified that the price of his family's health insurance
was increasing, he paid extra money.

He did not want to take any risks.

He accepted that he'd have to pay out of pocket to see a specialist or hospital
consultant.

He even accepted having co-payments for the health insurance plan
that he purchased.

But he did not envisage being told that his family's health insurance policy did
not fully cover his young daughter for a relatively basic eye operation in the
private hospital where she was a patient of a consultant ophthalmologist.

The Cumiskyes' policy did not cover the procedure in the Mater Private Hospital,
which is deemed a high-tech hospital.

So Cumiskey decided to call Temple Street
Children's Hospital, in Dublin, where his daughter's consultant also practised.

There, Cumiskey discovered, his family's private health insurance policy was
completely redundant.

The hospital has a common waiting list.

Children with
private health insurance join the same queue as children without private health
insurance.

Cumiskey is understandably frustrated.

I've paid out about EUR 10,000 [in health insurance] over the past five years.

Temple Street confirmed that it has a common waiting list, with a spokeswoman
saying:    Children with private health insurance join the same waiting list as
those without insurance.

And the issue is not limited to paediatric care.

Doctors said they are coming across a growing number of patients who are
insured but not covered  .

They are patients who have bought cheap plans that
solely provide cover in public hospitals, or plans that require considerable
co-payments in standalone private hospitals.

Doctors said the problem was exacerbated by the introduction of the health
insurance 'late entry' levy, which comes into force from the end of next month.

The Lifetime Community Rating is designed to encourage younger customers to take
out health insurance.

It will mean that people over the age of 34 who take out
health insurance for the first time, or after a long break, will face a 2 per
cent per year penalty on the price of their health insurance.

Many are
purchasing cheaper plans.

A health insurance insider who spoke with this newspaper said insurers were
aware that some of these plans were of limited value, but said they provide many
30-40 year olds with an opportunity to get into the market and avoid any loading
that might occur down the line.

According to the Health Insurance Authority, there are 379 plans on the market.

Fifty of those solely cover care in public hospitals.

Consultant ophthalmologist Michael O'Keeffe said it had become a nightmare for
people to understand the level of cover they have.

O'Keeffe and other doctors said the very basic health insurance cover is of
little or no use to people.

They said people are sold these policies with the
view that they have special privileges in public hospitals.

They think they will get a private room or a semi-private bed.

There are no separate lists in public hospitals for private health insurance
policy-holders.

They will have to wait for an appointment and surgery dates like
a public patient,   said O'Keeffe.

If you are on a basic policy, your shortfall for cataract surgery in a private
hospital could be as much as EUR 1,800, or in fact EUR 2,500 in the likes of
Mater Private or Blackrock Clinic.

That is no cover at all, really.

You may as
well be a self-payer,   O'Keeffe said.

According to O'Keeffe, patients do not realise this until they have a
consultation and check with their insurers.

He said many patients become hugely
upset.

Dermot Goode, a health insurance broker with Total Health Cover, said about 15
per cent of people with private health insurance are on these 'public only'
plans.

Consultant neurosurgeon Ciarán Bolger said people were    throwing away their
money   on plans that solely cover treatment in public hospitals.

These cheap plans really annoy me, as they are worthless,   said Bolger.

Bolger operates at Beaumont Hospital and also at the Hermitage Clinic.

He said
he can provide quicker treatment for patients who have a health insurance plan
that covers the Hermitage Clinic - but not all do.

Then they must join a waiting
list at Beaumont.

Bolger said he    did not know of a hospital, or of any consultants, with
separate waiting lists [in public hospitals].

He also said that patients with cheap health insurance plans could find
themselves at a    disadvantage  , as public waiting list initiatives    favour
those without insurance  .

Bolger spoke of the National Purchase Treatment Fund (NPTF) and the Special
Delivery Unit (SDU), which alleviated the pressure on waiting lists in public
hospitals by paying for public patients to be treated in separate private
facilities.

Those initiatives did not look after private patients who may have found
themselves in the same queue, he said.

A consultant who works at Dublin's Mater Misericordiae Hospital said patients
with private health insurance did not receive speedier access.

He said    there
[was] essentially no elective service   at the hospital    as the service is
swamped with trauma and tumour cases.

Appropriately, insurance has no effect on
waiting times for these cases and they are treated based on priority.

Some elective surgery is planned in the Mater because the magnitude of the
surgery necessitates access to the resources of the large teaching hospital.

In
these cases, there is no benefit to having insurance, but this is overwhelmingly
due to the general conditions regarding access in public hospitals,   the
consultant told The Sunday Business Post.

Consultants at various other hospitals said the same.

Anecdotally, there is talk within medical circles of some consultants managing
to prioritise private patients from whom they can make money.

I have heard anecdotal comments in the past about surgeons, in particular,
having a very large percentage of private patients in their admissions
inconsistent with the distribution of private patients in their locality,   one
doctor admitted.

The doctor added that he would not like to    depend on this as a private
patient  .

The
HSE said public and voluntary hospitals are supposed to operate common waiting
lists for patients, irrespectively whether they have health insurance.

Private hospital founder Jimmy Sheehan said the sheer number of    confusing
plans   was    an absolute nightmare   for doctors and patients.

We have given up trying to tell people whether they are covered at Blackrock
[Clinic] and Galway [Clinic], as it is so confusing,   he said.

Sheehan said that patients did not realise they were being sold a pup by health
insurers promoting cheap health insurance plans.

He said that co-payments - for
some health insurance plans - were often prohibitively expensive for patients
seeking care in private hospitals, and that this resulted in some patients with
health insurance being forced back into the public system.

The system is chaotic and people are being treated appallingly,   said Sheehan.

Are they really as bad as the doctors say?

They are,   said health insurance broker Dermot Goode.

LOAD-DATE: March 18, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                     Copyright 2015 Post Publications Ltd.
                              All Rights Reserved


                              124 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                              India Insurance News

                       July 12, 2016 Tuesday 6:30 AM EST

Missed 2016 Open Enrollment Period?

Term Health Insurance is Best Option

LENGTH: 379  words


July 12 -- AgileHealthInsurance.com, the Internet's first site dedicated to
helping consumers understand the value of term health insurance, announced today
it has added additional plans for consumers seeking coverage outside of the open
enrollment period.

Open enrollment for 2016 Obamacare coverage ended Jan. 31, 2016, but people can
still enroll in term health insurance.

Term health insurance covers doctor
visits, hospitalization, emergency care and other common medical needs.

Term health insurance represents a distinct category of health insurance that is
generally more affordable than Obamacare plans or COBRA.

The average monthly
premium for term health insurance plans selected on AgileHealthInsurance.com is
less than $100.

Eligibility requirements and flexibility in benefits contribute
to the cost savings realized by consumers.

In addition, term health insurance
plans do not have the same narrow network limitations associated with many
exchange health plans.

Consumers can now compare term health plans from various insurers at
AgileHealthInsurance.com, including UnitedHealthcare, Everest Group, Unified
Life Insurance Co., Companion Life Insurance Co. and Standard Life.

Agile
customers can also enroll in Foundation dental and vision plans underwritten by
Nationwide.

"For people who missed open enrollment and are blocked by the new special
enrollment rules, term health insurance is an excellent option," said Bruce
Telkamp, CEO and co-founder of AgileHealthInsurance.com.

"These plans offer
consumers a broad range of benefit options that help individuals and families
find affordable coverage they can purchase any time of year."

Unlike Obamacare plans, consumer applications are approved or rejected based on
health status, including the nature of pre-existing conditions.

Additionally,
consumers may still be subject to the Obamacare Tax unless they qualify for one
of several exemptions.

However, the lower cost of term health insurance means
that even for some consumers facing the tax penalty, the combination of penalty
and premium is still less expensive than an unsubsidized Obamacare premium.

To learn more about term health insurance, visit AgileHealthInsurance's Learning
Center at www.AgileHealthInsurance.com.

Source: AgileHealthInsurance.com

                              125 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                          The Lebanon Democrat, Tenn.

Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           November 15, 2014 Saturday

Wilson county businesses help navigate Affordable Care Act open enrollment

BYLINE: Xavier Smith, The Lebanon Democrat, Tenn.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 770 words


Nov. 15--Some local medical agencies plan to help ease the mind of folks who may
be confused or unsure about their health care future.

PharmaCare and University Medical Center plan to counsel and assist those who
need guidance when choosing a health care coverage plan under the new Patient
Protection and Affordable Care Act (ACA), known commonly as "Obamacare."

The law, which President Obama signed into effect in 2010, requires Americans to
be covered under a health insurance plan by Feb. 2015.

Anyone who fails to
enroll in one of the several health insurance options by that time would be
subject to penalties by the government, unless the failure is due to certain
circumstances.

The ACA open enrollment period is a time set aside for individuals who are
eligible to enroll in a Qualified Health Plan in the Health Insurance
Marketplace.

The open enrollment period for coverage starting in 2015 is from
Nov. 15 to Feb. 15, 2015.

Beginning Saturday, University Medical Center will help area residents learn
about and enroll in health insurance options on the Health Insurance
Marketplace.

Nearly 10 million uninsured individuals enrolled in a marketplace
plan during the first enrollment wave, but 30 million remain uninsured.

"As a primary health provider in Wilson County, we want to help educate
residents in an easy-to-understand way, as well as assist those who haven't yet
signed up for health insurance or Medicaid, if qualified," said Matt Caldwell,
CEO of University Medical Center.

"During the next few months, we'll be going
out in the community to educate consumers, hosting in-hospital events and
meeting one-on-one to help these individuals find affordable coverage for
themselves and their family."

PharmaCare will provide a free Medicare consultation with a pharmacist to help
seniors pick the best prescription drug plan or Medicare Advantage plan based on
their current list of medications.

The open enrollment period for choosing a Medicare plan is currently ongoing and
will end Dec. 7.

PharmaCare pharmacists will also help citizens by providing information to
compare plans within the ZIP code where residents live and give a printed review
of those plans.

The Health Insurance Marketplace provides citizens access to affordable health
insurance coverage.

In accordance to the ACA, all health plans on the
marketplace must offer a comprehensive set of benefits, and individuals cannot
be denied coverage based on a pre-existing condition.

There are five different
categories of plans, and exact prices vary depending on location, age, household
size and coverage desire.

Bronze plans are designed so that insurance companies will typically pay 60
percent of covered health care expenses with the remaining 40 percent to be paid
by consumers.

The consumer's expenses will be in the form of out-of-pocket fees
over and above the cost of the plan's monthly premium.

Silver plans (standard plans) pay 70 percent of insurance costs, and the gold
plans pay 80 percent.

The platinum plan is the most robust and pays 90 percent of costs and has the
highest premiums.

In all cases, the lower the premium, the higher the deductible
will be.

There's also the catastrophic plan offered only to those 30 and under or those
with the hardship exemption.

These plans contain very basic coverage and have
very narrow provider networks.

People can also apply for Medicaid or the Children's Health Insurance Program
(CHIP) at any time of year.

If the applicants qualify, they can enroll
immediately.

Anyone who can afford health insurance coverage but doesn't sign up may have to
pay a penalty of $325 per adult, $162.50 per child -- up to $975 per family or 2
percent of a family's income, whichever is higher.

However, there are certain exclusions to penalties for not signing up for health
care insurance coverage.

People may qualify for exemption if: they're uninsured for less than 3 months of
the year, the lowest-priced coverage available would be more than 8 percent of
the household income, they're a member of a federally recognized tribe or
eligible for services through an Indian Health Service, and other reasons.

To schedule an appointment with PharmaCare pharmacists, which can be completed
in person or over the phone, call 615-758-4750 and select option 2.

University Medical Center's application counselors can perform the same analysis
and help with the sign-up process.

To make an appointment to meet with an
application counselor, call 615-444-8262, ext.

___ (c)2014 The Lebanon Democrat, Tenn. Visit The Lebanon Democrat, Tenn. at
www.lebanondemocrat.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

LOAD-DATE: November 16, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

ACC-NO:
20141115-1LD-Wilson-county-businesses-help-navigate-Affordable-Care-Act-open-enr
ollment-1115-20141115

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: 1LD


                                 Copyright 2014


                              126 of 999 DOCUMENTS



                            Legal Monitor Worldwide

                            November 15, 2013 Friday

Medicare Open Enrollment Does Not Include New Health Insurance Exchanges, Says
Attorney With The Hale Law Firm

LENGTH: 380  words


The open enrollment period for Medicare has begun, when beneficiaries can sign
up for private health plans.

However, this should not be confused with the new health insurance exchanges
that also began operations recently.

John D. Hale, a prominent Dallas elder law
attorney, explains the difference.

"During the open enrollment period, which runs from October 15 to December 7,
Medicare beneficiaries may sign up for Medicare Advantage plans and Medicare
Part D prescription drug plans," said Hale.

"The health insurance exchanges, by
contrast, are for people who do not have health insurance, through Medicare or
otherwise."

Hale said there was potential for confusion, because the open enrollment period
for Medicare overlaps with the enrollment period for the health insurance
exchanges, which is from October 1 through March 31.

To add to the confusion,
many health insurance companies have used terms such as "silver," "gold" or
"platinum" for products they make available to Medicare beneficiaries, and now,
such terms are also being used for different health insurance packages available
on the exchanges.

One insurer, SummaCare, has changed the names of its Medicare Advantage plans
from silver and gold to sapphire and emerald, to help reduce confusion.

People on Medicare should make sure they are reviewing Medicare plans, not
marketplace options.

Medicare is not part of the marketplace, and Medicare
beneficiaries can safely ignore the new health insurance exchanges.

Insurance companies are not permitted to sell
policies that duplicate Medicare benefits to Medicare beneficiaries.

What people on Medicare can do during the open enrollment period is shop around
for Medicare Part D prescription drug plans and all-in-one Medicare Advantage
plans.

This may be a good idea if a beneficiary's health or medication has
changed.

Many Part D plans have increased co-payments or premiums, or changed
the pricing tiers for medications.

Medicare beneficiaries can shop for a new
plan or see what their options are by using the Plan Finder at www.medicare.gov
.

"The open enrollment plan is a good time for Medicare beneficiaries to shop
around," said Hale.

"Just remember that there is no need to worry about the new
health insurance exchanges."

LOAD-DATE: November 16, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              127 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                       Telegram & Gazette (Massachusetts)

                    May 22, 2000 Monday, RT.

9 WEST EDITION

Ware surveys insurance;
 Committee eyes 3 different plans

BYLINE: J.P. Ellery; CORRESPONDENT

SECTION: LOCAL NEWS; Pg.

B1

LENGTH: 672 words

DATELINE: WARE



- An ad hoc committee hopes payment incentives will entice some of the town's
full-time employees to change to a lesser-priced health insurance plan -- and
save the town money.

Peter V. Thamel and Roger H. Pariseau, of the Health Insurance Committee, said
in a weekend interview that this is just a vehicle to be used by town
negotiators in pending contract talks with various town employee unions.

The success of the proposed plan is contingent on how many of the town's roughly
250 full-time employees might accept the coverage changes -- and that number is
unknown, they said.

None of this is short-term,'' Mr. Pariseau said.

It's all figured for
long-term'' savings and benefits.

Years ago, Ware town employees were among the first in the region to receive
health insurance paid 90 percent by the town.

Back then, the cost was considered
reasonable, but over the years, health insurance costs have steadily climbed.

Ware officials have for decades looked to bring such expenses down.

Donna L.
Pulchtopek, the selectmen's assistant, said the town's total annual cost for
town employees' health insurance, including retired teachers, is about $1.3
million.

In a report Tuesday to the Board of Selectmen, the ad hoc Health Insurance
Committee recommended the town stay with Blue Cross/Blue Shield health
insurance, but offer employees three Blue Cross plans at differing costs.

Instead of providing just Master Medical, at $689 a month for a family plan, the
committee proposed adding the less-expensive BlueCare Elect and HMO Blue plans.

If younger town employees opted for Blue Care or HMO Blue instead of Master
Medical, Mr. Pariseau said, the town could offer a one-time payment to that
employee of $1,039 to change to BlueCare Elect, or $1,543 to switch to HMO Blue.

Those sums are the town's annual savings per employee for such a switch, the
committee said.

The reason why we thought people might want to do this,'' Mr. Thamel said, is
that ... if you're a younger person in your late 20s or early 30s ... when
people are pretty healthy ... you might want to have more money in your
pocket.''

The committee also recommended paying town employees whose insurance coverage is
provided through a spouse's employer to stay off the town's plan.

The stipend
payment would be 10 percent of the town's annual savings for every year the town
employee remains on a spouse's insurance plan: roughly $600 a year.

RETIREES' BENEFIT

Extending health insurance benefits to all retired town employees also could be
an incentive for present town employees to switch health insurance plans, the
committee said.

At the May 8 annual town meeting, voters approved seeking a special act of the
state Legislature to provide 50 percent town paid health insurance for retired
town employees.

Only retired teachers now get such a benefit in Ware.

In three prior ballot votes over the years, residents had defeated requests to
provide the remaining retired town employees with health insurance; then a
petition by town employees for the legislative act was passed at the recent
annual town meeting.

Mr. Pariseau asked Tuesday that selectmen hold off on petitioning the
Legislature for the special health insurance act.

He said over the weekend that, if town and employee unions work out insurance
savings for Ware, it is hoped that part of that agreement would allow retired
workers to receive 90 percent town-paid health insurance instead of the 50
percent OK'd at the May 9 annual town meeting.

We wanted people to think long-term ... to get some kind of health insurance
once they've retired,'' Mr. Thamel said.

So, you've got to give up something
now if you want to get something later.''

Under the committee's overall plan, selectmen would decide how many years an
employee must work to be eligible for retirees' health insurance, the committee
said.

The committee also recommended that 50 percent town-paid insurance be provided
to a surviving spouse of a town employee or retiree.

LOAD-DATE: May 23, 2000

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

               Copyright 2000 Worcester Telegram & Gazette, Inc.


                              128 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                              India Insurance News

                       August 30, 2013 Friday 6:30 AM EST

Arch Business: Three Popular Insurance Programs for Those with Pre-Existing
Conditions Ending Soon

LENGTH: 365  words


New Delhi, Aug. 30 -- Effective January 1st, 2014, three of the most popular
methods for providing health insurance coverage for people with pre-existing
conditions will come to an end.

Coverage with two of these health insurance
programs, HIPAA and PCIP, will end on December 31st, and enrollments on the
third "State Continuation" program will be denied after January 1st, 2014.

Individuals currently in these three groups, including those with pre-existing
conditions, are expected to obtain full coverage for their pre-existing
conditions using plans available in the Open Market or on the new Nevada Health
Insurance Exchange.

In the past, it was common for individuals who completed COBRA continuation
coverage from their prior employer to sign-up for an individual HIPAA (Health
Insurance Portability and Accountability Act) health insurance plan.

This Act requires individual health insurance companies to offer their two most
popular plans to those individuals that have completed their COBRA coverage.

The
monthly premiums that the insurance companies charge for HIPAA plans is
restricted by statute, but the general experience for most were high premium
rates.

Effective December 31st, 2013, all HIPAA plans in all states, including Nevada,
will come to an end.

Everyone that has had HIPAA coverage in the past, or will be having their COBRA
coverage terminated in the future, are expected to obtain guaranteed issue
coverage either through the Open Market or through their State Health Insurance
Exchange.

The Pre-Existing Condition Insurance Plan (PCIP) is another method that many
people used since the ACA was enacted for their pre-existing conditions.

PCIP
plans cover a broad range of benefits, including hospital visits, primary and
specialty care, and costs for prescriptions.

PCIP plans have a $2,000 annual
medical deductible, a $500 annual prescription deductible, and they pay 70% of
the in-network medical expenses after the deductible has been satisfied.

All PCIP plans in all states, including Nevada, will terminate on December 31st,
2013.

Members currently enrolled in PCIP are expected to make application for a
new 2014 guaranteed issue individual health insurance plan.

LOAD-DATE: August 31, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Web Publication

Arch Business: Three Popular Insurance Programs for Those with Pre-Existing
Conditions Ending Soon

LENGTH: 365  words


New Delhi, Aug. 30 -- Effective January 1st, 2014, three of the most popular
