                              189 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                            The Tribune, Elkin, N.C.

Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             June 1, 2011 Wednesday

Elkin to improve employees' insurance, base salary and merit compensation

BYLINE: Brett Willis, The Tribune, Elkin, N.C.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 844 words


June 01--If Elkin's 2011-12 budget is approved next month, all town employees
will receive a higher base salary, merit compensation and an improved health
insurance plan.

Set aside in the upcoming fiscal year's proposed budget are funds to secure a
one percent increase in both base salary and merit compensation for the town's
53 employees.

The one percent "across the board" payroll increase adds $23,568.28 to next
year's budget and was agreed to unanimously by commissioners during a workshop
held last week.

Commissioners also approved a raise in merit compensation for town employees.

Elkin's policy of merit compensation was first adopted during last year's town
budget discussions.

Merit comp is performance-based and is given to each town
employee on an individual basis by the employee's department supervisor.

The
one-time check, which is not included in the employee's salary, cannot exceed
1.5 percent of the individual's annual pay.

The average raise amounts to one percent of the employee's yearly wages, said
Elkin Town Manager Lloyd Payne.

Town employees would also have the option of signing up for a health insurance
plan that offers more comprehensive coverage than does the current plan, which
offers employees and their families only basic health coverage.

"We would like to get our employees off of the bottom tier of insurance
coverage.

Our employees' plans are way below those of our peer cities," said
Payne.

In the 2010-11 fiscal year, all 53 Town of Elkin employees purchased health
insurance through their jobs.

Both the town's current and prospective plans are
through the Municipal Insurance Trust of North Carolina, which is sponsored by
the NC League of Municipalities.

Elkin Assistant Town Manager/Financial Director John Holcomb added, "We are on
the lowest plan offered by the League of Municipalities currently."

While the proposed plan would lower deductibles and copays for primary and
specialist visits from $30 and $40 to $20 and $30, respectively, it would
particularly benefit town employees who cover their children on their health
insurance.

The rate for employees and children would drop from $543 in the
town's current health insurance plan to $378 under the new plan.

With a four percent increase to the town's current health insurance plan
anticipated in the coming year, commissioners believed it a good time for an
upgrade.

"The timing is right to make good on our health insurance," said Commissioner
Joe Walker.

Lowe also supported the upgraded health
insurance plan.

Although not directly challenging a transition to the new plan, Commissioner
Cicely McCulloch added to the discussion, "I have a basic plan myself, and the
lower the copay, the more often you go to the doctor."

Still, commissioners ultimately agreed to budget an additional $17,322 for the
proposed plan, bringing Elkin's total health insurance bill to $30,096 -- a 9.5
percent increase from last year.

Improvements to base salaries, merit compensation rates and health insurance
policies are all initiatives to retain town employees, according to Payne.

To justify spending increases on salary and insurance, Payne pointed to a report
on the Elkin Police Department conducted within the past five years, which found
that officers were beginning their law enforcement careers in Elkin to receive
training before moving to comparably-sized or larger markets soon after their
training was complete.

Even in other municipalities of a similar size to Elkin
they could receive significantly more pay and better benefits.

"The emphasis of the previous report on our police department found that's why
it's a training ground," said Payne explaining that relatively low compensation
was the primary reason officers cited for leaving Elkin.

In response to Payne, Commissioner Walker asked that town administration go back
into employment records to tally how many Town of Elkin employees left last year
and to find out their reasons for doing so.

"We need to take a look at all those people who left and see what we can do
about it.

I want to know how many people we lost and why, and I'll ask that
question every year I sit here," said Walker in his request for a record of
departmental turnover.

Payne agreed to retrieve the data to present to the board at a later meeting.

In the meantime, with better pay and benefits proposed in the next year's
budget, town officials are looking to make Elkin a more attractive place to live
-- and work -- for what is hopefully a long period of time.

To see more of The Tribune, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.elkintribune.com/.

For more information
about the content services offered by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services
(MCT), visit www.mctinfoservices.com.

                               India Pharma News

                    December 10, 2014 Wednesday 6:30 AM EST

NC Get Covered Reminds North Carolinians to Enroll by Dec. 15 for Jan. 2015
Health Coverage

LENGTH: 627  words


Dec. 10 -- US-based NC Get Covered issued the following news release:

Affordable health insurance is helping thousands of North Carolinians receive
quality health care.

NC Get Covered, a non-partisan initiative powered by The
Big Tent Coalition, reminds residents without health insurance not to be left
behind.

North Carolinians must enroll in a health insurance plan by Dec. 15 in
order to receive coverage by Jan. 1.

With only two months left to enroll, North Carolinians have compelling reasons
for purchasing health insurance:

* Health care can be expensive; up to $3,000 for a broken arm.

* Health insurance gives a person access to preventive care, diagnostic tests,
and more.

* Financial help is available to make premiums fit your budget.

"The Affordable Care Act (ACA) insurance has already saved lives in North
Carolina," said Sorien Schmidt, Get Covered America's North Carolina state
director.

"We have talked to consumers who have been diagnosed and undergone
life-saving surgeries using their coverage.

The marketplace plans are
affordable, and meet consumers' needs and budgets.

We encourage uninsured North
Carolinians to check out their options."

For most, there are fines for not purchasing a health insurance plan.

Each adult
without health insurance will have to pay $325 or two percent of their annual
household income, whichever is greater, the following year for not purchasing
health insurance.

To avoid these fines, North Carolinians should keep in mind
the following enrollment deadlines:

* Dec. 15, 2014 - Last date to enroll for health insurance coverage starting on
Jan. 1, 2015.

* Jan. 15, 2015 - Last date to enroll for health insurance coverage starting on
Feb. 1, 2015.

* Feb. 15, 2015 - Last date to enroll for health insurance coverage for 2015.

Through NC Get Covered, North Carolinians have access to in-person assisters and
resources to help them navigate the open enrollment process.

NC Get Covered
offers statewide enrollment assistance, including outreach events and
educational ACA resources for financial help, health insurance basics, and ACA
deadlines and fines.

"It's crucial that North Carolinians are aware that there are deadlines and
fines associated with not enrolling in a health insurance plan," said Lee Dixon,
project coordinator for NC Get Covered.

"While North Carolina was one of the few
states to reach its enrollment goal last year, there is still work to be done to
ensure that everyone finds the best health insurance plan for their needs and
budget.

NC Get Covered is available for all North Carolinians to help ease the
burden of finding the right health insurance plan."

Free, in-person enrollment help is available for consumers who want to talk to
an expert about their options, right in their community.

Here are some upcoming
enrollment events taking place across the state:

* Greensboro - Saturday, December 13 at the Warnersville Recreational Center,
601 Doak Street (10 a.m. - 4 p.m.)

* Charlotte - Saturday, December 13 at the Children & Family Services Center,
601 East 5th Street (10 a.m. - 4 p.m.)

* Durham - Saturday, December 13 at the Centro de Alabanza Naciones Unidas, 2100
Chapel Hill Road (9 a.m.-3 p.m.)

* Raleigh - Monday, December 15 at the Pullen Park Community Center, 408 Ashe
Avenue (1:30pm- 7:30pm)

Walk-in appointments are available at the sites.

Consumers can also schedule
free appointments any day in their county by calling 1-855-733-3711 or visiting
(www.getcoveredamerica.org/connector/) and entering their ZIP code to locate an
in-person assister nearby.

For more information about enrollment assistance and ACA-related information
such as financial help, and ACA deadlines and fines, go to
(www.NCGetCovered.org).

Source: NC Get Covered

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                    April 15, 1996, Monday, JOURNAL EDITION

Medicare to offer 4 new health plans

BYLINE: Laura Williamson; STAFF WRITER

SECTION: STATE NEWS; Pg.

01A

LENGTH: 321 words


By the end of the year, metro Atlanta and north Georgia Medicare patients will
have four new health plans to choose from.

The Health Care Financing Administration (HCFA) in Washington, which runs the
federal health insurance program for the elderly, announced today it had
selected 25 managed care plans from eight cities and five rural areas nationwide
to take part in a pilot program dubbed Medicare Choices.

Hundreds of thousands of senior citizens in metro Atlanta and north Georgia
could begin enrolling in one of the four Georgia plans chosen as early as this
summer, HCFA officials said.

All plans are expected to be open to patients by
December.

HCFA officials said the program will test ways to save taxpayers money by
enrolling senior citizens in a range of managed care plans, some similar to
those offered by private employers.

Medicaid, the state- federal health
insurance program for the poor, began requiring metro Atlanta patients to switch
to managed care this year.

Georgia's Medicare options will include plans run by hospitals and doctors, a
new way of providing health insurance also emerging in the private sector.

"This is our chance to prove that we don't have to be micromanaged by insurance
companies to provide health care," said Don Hutton, chairman and CEO of the
Morgan Health Group, a network of 300 primary care physicians in the Atlanta
area and one of the four Georgia plans chosen by HCFA.

The others are plans run by St. Joseph's Health System, Georgia Baptist Health
Care System and Value Health Inc.

Senior citiizens who don't want to enroll in one of the new plans won't have to.

But some plans will try to entice them by covering services not included in
Medicare, such as annual dental exams and prescription drugs, allowing them to
drop costly Medigap policies.

Seniors will continue to pay their $ 46 monthly
Medicare premiums no matter which plan they choose.

LOAD-DATE: July 17, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                  April 10, 1991, WEDNESDAY, FIVE STAR Edition

COVERAGE FOR GROWN 'DEPENDENTS'

BYLINE: Bethe Growe and Nancy Dilley

SECTION: EVERYDAY MAGAZINE; Pg.

5E

LENGTH: 659 words


Q: My daughter will soon be graduating from college.

When she does, she will no
longer be considered my ''dependent'' under my company's group health insurance
plan, so she will not have any health insurance coverage.

I work for a large
corporation that has its insurance through an insurance company.

I am worried
about keeping my daughter insured until she finds a job.

A: Your daughter
should be able to continue her health insurance coverage through your employer's
health insurance plan for up to 36 months.

In many instances, if an employee or
an employee's dependent loses health care coverage under an employer's group
health plan, that person must be given the right to continue the coverage, at
his or her own expense.

For most employers with more than 20 full-time
employees, this is required by the Consolidated Omnibus Reconciliation Act,
known as ''COBRA.''

Under the law, your daughter would be eligible to continue
her health insurance coverage even though she is no longer considered your
''dependent'' under your employer's health insurance plan.

To do this, one of
you must notify the plan administrator of the plan shortly before your daughter
''technically'' is no longer your dependent.

The administrator is then obligated
to notify you or your daughter of your daughter's right to continue the health
insurance coverage and how to go about doing so.

Your daughter will then have
at least 60 days to elect the continuation coverage.

If she does so, your
employer may pay some or all of the cost of the premium to the insurance company
to continue the insurance, although this is unusual.

In any event, your employer
cannot charge your daughter more than 102 percent of the premium it pays to the
insurance company for covering a person similar to your daughter.

The group
health plan is required by law to provide the continuation coverage for at least
36 months from the time your daughter is no longer considered to be your
dependent under the plan.

This maximum period can be shortened if your daughter
does not pay any required premium payment on time (if she is obligated to do so)
or if she becomes covered under another employer's group health plan, as an
employee or otherwise.

Q: Can I have a living trust made for my sister?

She has
quite a few assets, but she is ill and sometimes not aware of what she is doing.

A: The answer depends on your sister's mental alertness.

As we have mentioned in
prior columns, a living trust is a good way to manage property in case of
disability during lifetime and to avoid the problems of probate at death.

A
person creates a living trust by signing an agreement and transferring all of
his or her assets to the trustee of the trust.

Of course, the trustee can be the
same person as the creator of the trust.

In order to sign the trust agreement,
the creator of the trust must be alert enough to understand what he or she is
signing.

Even though you might arrange with an attorney to have a living trust
prepared for your sister, she would still have to sign the trust agreement.

And
to sign the agreement, your sister would have to understand what she is signing.

If your sister is not well enough to understand the trust agreement, then she
could not sign it.

There is one way around this problem.

Perhaps your sister
signed a durable power of attorney sometime when she was not so ill.

If she did
and if the power specifically gave permission to you (or someone else) to create
a living trust for your sister, then you (or the named person) could create a
living trust for your sister.

Bethe Growe and Nancy Dilley are St. Louis
attorneys specializing in retirement planning and benefits, estate planning and
probate.

Send your questions or comments to them in care of the St. Louis
Post-Dispatch, 900 North Tucker Boulevard, St. Louis, Mo.

Because of the
volume of questions received, not all can be printed, and personal replies are
not possible.

LOAD-DATE: October 13, 1993

LANGUAGE: English

                  Copyright 1991 St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Inc.

                              193 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                            February 16, 2007 Friday
                                 THIRD EDITION

Blunt offers health insurance plan

BYLINE: By Virginia Young POST-DISPATCH JEFFERSON CITY BUREAU CHIEF

SECTION: METRO; Pg.

C1

LENGTH: 674 words

DATELINE: JEFFERSON CITY


His proposal

STATE POOL o Small businesses would set aside money for a health insurance
program that would be administered by a state clearinghouse.

WORKER SUBSIDIES o Low-wage employees would get subsidies, with some of the
money coming from state funds and some from Medicaid.

Matt Blunt unveiled a plan Thursday that he said would help low-income,
working adults buy health insurance.

The plan's centerpiece is a state clearinghouse that would let small businesses
pool their risks.

The companies would have to set aside money for each employee
to spend on health insurance offered by the clearinghouse.

Workers would pick a plan and pay their share of the cost with tax-free dollars.

Low-wage employees would get subsidies, with $20 million coming from state funds
and $32 million from federal Medicaid funds.

Blunt said the plan would "significantly expand the number of people who have
access to health insurance."

Blunt would not estimate how many would get
coverage.

About 700,000 Missourians lack health insurance now.

Experts called the governor's plan a good first step.

"Efforts to pool are good," said Sidney Watson, professor of law at the Center
for Health Law Studies at St. Louis University.

"The more people we can pool and
sell insurance to, the better rate we get."

But Watson and some Democrats said the plan would do nothing for people below
the poverty level who lost Medicaid coverage two years ago.

Some were elderly or
disabled and won't qualify for employer-based plans.

"It will help a small portion of people who are uninsured in Missouri," said
Rep. Sam Page, D-Creve Coeur.

"We still have 177,000 people who lost their
health insurance."

The 177,000 reflects the net reduction in the Medicaid rolls since March 2005.

It includes those dropped because the Legislature tightened eligibility, as well
as those who were declared ineligible when Blunt began verifying recipients'
incomes.

House Small Business Committee Chairman Doug Ervin, R-Kearney, has introduced
the governor's plan.

Ervin's bill has 58 co-sponsors, including several
Democrats.

Ervin said one goal of the bill is to make consumers more conscious of the cost
of their health care choices.

But he said they rarely evaluate
health care services based on cost.

"We are fundamentally changing the way we think about health insurance," Ervin
said.

"The whole idea is to promote ownership.

Nobody spends any money as
carefully as they spend their own."

Ervin said he hopes the plan would reduce the number of uninsured by at least 20
percent.

Last year, a state working group found that about 300,000 Missourians work at
small businesses that do not offer health insurance.

The plan unveiled Thursday follows Blunt's goal of subsidizing the purchase of
private insurance instead of expanding public programs.

In that vein, he also wants to cut the franchise tax for businesses that offer
health insurance and change the law so that people can take their insurance with
them when they change jobs.

His pooling plan would establish a quasi-governmental entity called the Missouri
Health Insurance Exchange.

To oversee the agency, the bill would set up a
nine-member board consisting of state officials, legislators and private-sector
members appointed by the governor.

While the bill does not limit the size of businesses that could participate,
officials said the goal would be to cover businesses employing 50 or fewer
workers.

The premium subsidies would go to those earning less than twice the federal
poverty level - for example, a single worker earning less than $20,420.

Brad Jones, who lobbies for the National Federation of Independent Business,
said the governor's plan would let employees choose an insurance plan that fits
their needs.

"Our poor members have been getting reamed on health insurance costs for 20
years and I'm excited that we're finally seriously having a discussion about
it," he said.

---

STLtoday.com/links Read the health insurance bill.

LOAD-DATE: February 16, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                  Copyright 2007 St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved

                              194 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                               The Economic Times

                           December 24, 2016 Saturday

Insurance Queries answered by Antony Jacob from Apollo Munich Health Insurance

SECTION: INSURE

LENGTH: 431 words


I am a 32-year-old professional and have a health insurance provided by my
company.

I wish to top up my health insurance plan on my own.

What is the
procedure?

Once I approach the insurance provider, is there any medical
examination?

Who bears the cost of medical examination?

Is the premium decided
on the basis of medical test, apart from regular calculation?

Top-up health insurance plans provide an extra health care financing shield for
you in the most economical way, especially, when you have an employer-provided
base health insurance cover.

You can easily top up your current health insurance
policy, by either contacting an agent or reviewing various top-up options on the
Internet.You should ideally look for a top-up policy that gives you an option to
convert to a full-fledged health insurance plan close to your retirement.

To buy a top-up plan, all you need to do is to fill up an online application
form.

Most insurance companies do not ask for a medical examination while
purchasing a top-up plan of up to Rs.

5 lakh, unless there is a medical
adversity listed in the application form.

In cases where there is a medical
check-up required, the insurance company bears the cost for the same, once the
application is accepted.

A loading on premium or an exclusion may be levied
because of adverse results of a medical check-up.

I have a corporate health insurance policy
for Rs.

I bought a top up to extend the coverage to Rs.

Can I
claim tax rebate on it?

What are the tax incentives for buying a health
insurance policy?

First off, let me congratulate you for buying a top-up plan at a young age to
mitigate rising healthcare costs.

Top-up plans are often underrated plans and
their importance is clear when you leave a job and the new employer does not
offer a similar policy or offers a reduced cover.

You can certainly claim a tax rebate for your top-up plan as per The Income Tax
Act, Section 80D.

In order to avail maximum rebate under the Income Tax Act i.e.

25,000 for an individual, you could consider buying a critical illness
policy.

It will ensure that you are adequately covered for all kinds of
lifestyle diseases, which is a major concern for most people working in MNCs,
given the fast-paced lifestyles they lead.

Having said that, a health insurance
policy should be viewed as a financial planning tool to mitigate rising
healthcare costs and not just as a tax saving tool.

(Please send your queries on Insurance to et.insurance@timesgroup.com)

                    Cape Cod Times (Hyannis, Massachesetts)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            January 5, 2008 Saturday

Not having health insurance will cost even more

BYLINE: Cynthia McCormick, Cape Cod Times, Hyannis, Mass.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 1155 words


Jan. 5--If you didn't have health insurance under the new state mandate by Jan.
1, it's going to cost you $219.

But if you go another year without health insurance, the penalty could be as
much as $912.

State officials say they will get the money -- this year by denying individuals
the personal tax exemption, or, next year, by deducting the penalty from tax
refunds or sending out bills.

A new statewide database will track who has health
insurance and who doesn't, they say.

The Massachusetts health insurance law passed under former Gov.

Mitt Romney
requries every state resident to have health insurance.

It provides low-cost, subsidized health insurance for poorer residents, but
higher income individuals must purchase private-pay plans.

About 300,000 people have signed up for health care plans since enrollment
started last year, including about 160,000 in the new state-subsidized plan
called Commonwealth Care.

It covers those who earn too much for the state's
Medicaid health plan, known as MassHealth, but too little to afford private
plans.

About 63,000 individuals have signed up for private-pay plans since the law went
into effect, state officials said.

They are not sure how many residents are still without health insurance.

At the start of enrollment, estimates of the state's uninsured ranged from
300,000 to 600,000, said.

A recent Barnstable County report, Monitoring the
Human Condition Study 2007, estimates that about 18 percent of Cape residents
lack health insurance.

The tax penalties for not having health insurance -- the first of their kind in
the nation -- are aimed at nudging people who can afford it toward being fully
covered, he said.

People who didn't have health insurance by Jan. 1 will lose their personal tax
exemption of $219 for the tax year 2007.

"The penalty for 2007 was relatively modest," said Richard Powers, spokesman for
the Massachusetts Health Connector, the state entity that handles enrollment in
state subsidized health-care plans.

"It's significantly more in 2008.

We hope it
will act as a catalyst for those who have thus far resisted purchasing health
insurance."

The state Department of Revenue has issued draft guidelines that would penalize
individuals up to $912 for not having health insurance by the end of 2008.

"If it's a married couple and neither had health insurance, it would be two
times that," said Robert R. Bliss, spokesman for the DOR.

Although the tax penalty for 2008 won't be assessed until tax returns are due in
2009, the penalties already are accumulating on a monthly basis against people's
future tax returns, Bliss said.

Penalties will be deducted from tax refunds.

If there is no refund or the
penalty is higher than the refund, the state will bill individuals in the same
way it would for taxes, Bliss said.The tax penalties for not having health
insurance by the end of 2009 probably will be even higher, Powers said.

The penalties are based on one-half the lowest cost plan available through the
Connector.

In 2009, the cost of that type of plans will go up since residents
will be required to have prescription coverage as part of their basic health
insurance plan.

The cheapest health-care plan available today to a 27-year-old privately insured
Boston resident, for example, is $193.81 a month, and that doesn't include
prescription coverage, Powers said.

Individuals will have insurance information forms to fill out with their tax
returns, Bliss said.

The information about what plans people have will be
checked against a state database.

"It's not just the honor system that's going to be employed here," he said.

Individuals without health insurance can be exempted from the tax penalties if
insurance is not affordable or they are facing unusual hardship, such as
homelessness or utility shutoffs, Powers s said.

The state has received 53 requests from residents who say they qualify for an
exemption from the law.

People are taking the penalties seriously, said Estelle Fritzinger, head of the
Community Action Committee of the Cape and Islands, which has a state contract
to enroll people in subsidized plans.

The agency anticipated a downturn in enrollment at the end of the year, she
said, but that hasn't happened.

"We're still seeing an average of 35 new
applications a day.

People are looking at the expenses they'll incur even under
the Commonwealth Care program versus the tax penalties," she said.

Subsidized health insurance through Commonwealth Care is available for
individuals earning up to $30,636 per year and for a family of four earning up
to $61,956.

The poorest of the poor pay no premium.

The maximum individuals can be charged
per month under Commonwealth Care is $105 per month.

The 2007 tax penalty of $219 is still much less money than paying the monthly
premium on even the lower cost Commonwealth Care programs.

But as the penalty increases, state officials hope that residents will see
having health insurance as a better use of their money.

"Otherwise, they will be paying over $900 a year and getting absolutely
nothing," Powers said.

Joyce Brennan, public information officer for the Southcoast Hospitals Group in
Southeastern Massachusetts said lower-income patients have been happy to sign up
for the state's new health insurance plans once they learn how to access the
system.

Employees of Southcoast -- which includes Tobey Hospital in Wareham, St.

Luke's in New Bedford and Charlton Memorial in Fall River -- tried calling about
14,000 people who have used free services at the hospitals, but many had moved
or had their phones disconnected.

"A lot of people are relieved to have the insurance," Brennan said.

It's reaching them that has been our barrier."

One Cape legislator wishes there were more opposition.

State Rep. Jeffrey Perry, R-Sandwich, said he hasn't heard of any legal
challenges to the state health insurance penalties yet, "but I certainly hope
there are."

Perry was one of only two legislators to vote against the health insurance
requirement in 2006.

He said that when
legislators discussed mandated coverage on the floor of the House, the only
incentives they talked about were education and the loss of the personal
exemption.

The state is "fining people for not buying private health insurance," he said.

To see more of the Cape Cod Times, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.capecodonline.com.

For reprints, email
tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                               The Economic Times

                           November 26, 2016 Saturday

Looking to buy a diabetes insurance plan?

Here's a low-down

BYLINE: Sunil Dhawan

SECTION: INSURE

LENGTH: 1246 words


Changing lifestyles are taking a toll on people's health.

The rising incidence
of diabetes is one such instance impacting an individuals' life, both physically
and financially.

Also known as the 'silent killer', the probability of
hospitalisation is high for diabetes patients, especially as they age.

The probability of having to pay large hospital bills, therefore, increases and
unless one has a dedicated and exclusive diabetes insurance plan, much of it
will have to be borne from one's own pocket.

According to an Association of
Physicians of India study, the urban poor spend as much as 34 per cent, while
their rural counterparts spend 27 per cent of their income on diabetes
treatment.

So how about buying a diabetes health insurance plan?

Any diabetes patient
between the ages of 18 and 65 is eligible to buy it.

What's more, there is no
waiting period in the diabetes specific insurance plans.

"Diabetes insurance
plans are specialised insurance plans focused on providing coverage on
treatments or expenses for people who suffer from diabetes," says Mahavir
Chopra, Director - Health, Life & Strategic Initiatives, Coverfox.com.

Diabetes insurance plans may be standalone and specifically covering the disease
or a part of a regular Mediclaim plan after paying extra premium.

Varishta
Mediclaim from National Insurance and Care Freedom from Religare Health
Insurance are two such plans, but they cater only to senior citizens.

'Diabetes
Safe' from Star Health Insurance and 'Energy' from Apollo Munich Health
Insurance are two exclusive diabetes insurance plans which anyone within the
eligible age bracket can buy, unlike the previous two.

The need for diabetes specific insurance plan

For a healthy individual, having a health cover plan like a Mediclaim, with
adequate sum insured, could be enough to meet the hospitalisation costs arising
out of a diabetic situation.

But future renewals and coverage may get impacted.

Therefore, on detection of diabetes, a diabetes specific insurance plan helps.

There could be further
complications caused due to diabetes, including heart disease, stroke, kidney
failure, vision loss and neuropathy or nerve damage.

Hence, for a diabetes
patient, a diabetes specific insurance plan can address the hospitalisation
concerns better.

There is another reason that makes diabetes specific insurance plan important.

"Generally, health insurance plans treat diabetes as a pre-existing disease and
put a waiting period on the policy, which is around 12 months to 2 years, but
can sometimes go up to 4 years.

So it is sensible to buy a diabetes specific
plan which is way more comprehensive than the health plans and also covers
various complexities," says Naval Goel, Founder & CEO, PolicyX.com.

Costlier than others

Buying a diabetes health insurance plan can, however, be costlier than other
disease specific plans.

It could be because of the rising incidence, so insurers
perceive higher risk of payouts, and also because the plan is a specialised
product.

Goel says, "The reason is quite obvious, even after taking into account
the problem of diabetes and its complications, there is a high probability that
the insured will outlive the policy term."

Life-long renewals beyond 65 years
are offered under all such plans.

Apollo Munich Health Insurance's 'Energy'

Apollo Munich Health Insurance offers 'Energy', a diabetes insurance plan for
those who have been diagnosed with Type II Diabetes or Prediabetes (Impaired
Fasting Glucose/Impaired Glucose Tolerance) or Hypertension.

There is no waiting
period and there is an option for co-payment of 20 per cent of the claim amount.

The plan also provides coverage for 144 day-care procedures.

There is a wellness
programme inbuilt in the plan which takes care of wellness tests and wellness
support that includes online data sharing and a wellness coach to help manage
diet and health.

In addition, the plan offers a renewal premium discount of up to 25 per cent for
the management of health conditions.

If there is no claim and the insured
manages his sugar to stay healthy, then he will get a discount.

Further,
reimbursements of up to 25 per cent of the renewal premium towards consultation,
medicines and drugs, diagnostic, dental and other miscellaneous medical expenses
not covered under any medical insurance will be applicable.

Do not merely base your buying decision by looking at premiums.

As the age band
changes, the premium amount also changes.

Star Health Insurance's 'Diabetes Safe'

Star Health Insurance's 'Diabetes Safe' covers hospitalisation expenses arising
out of complications of both type 1 and type 2 diabetes, and hospitalisation
expenses other than those related to complications.

Therefore, it's a kind of a
combo of Mediclaim and diabetes insurance plan.

The plan also covers out-patient
expenses for medical consultations, diagnostic tests, medicine and compensation
for the accidental death of the insured person.

There are two options:
Plan A, where pre-acceptance medical screening is compulsory, while in Plan B,
there is no pre-acceptance medical screening.

Rising incidence of diabetes

With diabetes on the rise because of changing lifestyles and genetic
predisposition, diabetes-related deaths in India have witnessed a 50 per cent
increase between 2005 and 2015.

It is now the seventh-most common cause of death
in the country, up from the 11th rank in 2005, according to data published by
the Global Burden of Disease (GBD), a WHO project.

There are 69.1 million
diabetes patients in India, the second-highest number in the world after China
(109 million).

According to the International Diabetes Federation (IDF)
estimates, India is predicted to have 123 million diabetes cases in the 20-79
age group by 2040.

Conclusion

As Ashish Mehrotra, MD & CEO, Max Bupa Health Insurance, says, "A comprehensive
health insurance plan covers multiple conditions and removes the worry of
managing multiple plans.

Also, when one can get the treatment for diabetes and
all other conditions under a single policy, then the need for specific cover
gets reduced."

If, however, diabetes is detected at a later stage, the future claim on the
plain-vanilla health insurance plan runs the risk of being jeopardised unless
the policyholder informs the insurer of any change in his medical condition.

In
other words, if the insured develops diabetes many years after buying the
regular insurance policy, even then it would be covered only if he informs the
insurer.

The insured would still be covered for diabetes as it was not
pre-existing, so diabetes cover would be relevant only in cases where the policy
is bought after the disease is discovered.

"Diabetes plans provide much needed immediate and specialised covers for such a
serious disease.

It is, therefore, worth investing in specialised health
insurance plan for diabetes as a supplementary cover to your regular health
insurance plan," says Chopra.

But even with an insurance to back the claims,
it's always better to stay healthy, do regular exercises, eat healthy diet, make
lifestyle changes, and have regular health check-ups.

Early diagnosis definitely
helps in limiting the damage, both physically and financially.

                              197 of 999 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                              July 29, 2013 Monday

Montana: Health Care Countdown - 2 Navigating New Insurance Malls

LENGTH: 624  words

DATELINE: Helena


Montana Wheat & Barley Committee, The State of Montana has issued the following
news release:

In the soon to be tumultuous world of health insurance, farm employers will have
to make some important financial decisions starting Oct. 1.

It's realistic to expect some glitches, but online health insurance marketplaces
will increase options for those without coverage or small businesses with costly
plans today, Iowa Insurance Commissioner Nick Gerhart said.

(DTN photo by
Elizabeth Williams)

That's when 50 state health care marketplaces (also called exchanges) will be
available online for small businesses and uninsured individuals to shop for
health care plans that meet 2014 insurance mandates under the Affordable Care
Act (ACA).

The marketplaces' function is to simply list the health plans offered by health
insurance companies that choose (and are qualified) to be in your state's
marketplace.

They'll also show each policy's premium based on the ages of those
covered, where you live, whether anyone smokes, and your income (to see if you
qualify for a tax credit or perhaps a premium subsidy).

One marketplace will be set up for individual policies and another will be
established for small businesses, called SHOPS (Small Business Health Options
Program).

In Iowa, six health insurance companies have submitted health plans to be listed
on its insurance marketplace, Iowa Insurance Commissioner Nick Gerhart told DTN.

However, the largest health insurer in Iowa, Wellmark Blue Cross and Blue
Shield, which has 86% of the individual health insurance policies in Iowa and
64% of the state's small business policies, won't participate in the state's
insurance marketplace until 2015.

In other states, several large insurance
companies are also opting out of the marketplaces the first year they're
offered.

UnitedHealthcare is participating in only 12 state marketplace
exchanges for 2014 and Cigna in only five.

Remember, there are two strong advantages of going with a marketplace-offered
plan: (1) small business health care tax credits, and (2) individual health
insurance tax subsidies will only be available for coverage purchased through a
state health insurance marketplace/exchange.

The Affordable Care Act requires everyone to have a health insurance policy, but
it does not force you to buy from a plan offered on your state's marketplace,
and in some cases you won't have to change your policy at all.

In Iowa, "well over half our Farm Bureau members will not see any change in
their plans as they are in what are called 'grandfathered plans' -- meaning they
can stay in those plans," said Steve Kammeyer with Farm Bureau Financial
Services in West Des Moines, Iowa.

"The rest of our members will have the option
of staying on their existing plan for at least another year because Wellmark
(the health insurance provider for Iowa Farm Bureau) has been granted an
extension on their renewal period."

Another important distinction in the law is only large employers (those with
more than 50 full-time equivalent employees) must provide health insurance for
their employees.

Most farm operations have fewer employees and they'll want to see how their
current insurance plan stacks up with those listed on their state's marketplace.

Because of the subsidies involved, it might be cheaper to have your non-family
employees buy their own subsidized individual health policy offered through the
marketplace.

HOW IT'S SUPPOSED TO WORK

You plug in your personal information -- income level (to see if you qualify for
subsidized premium), your age, your address, whether you smoke, if you are
married and/or have children.

For further information please visit: http://wbc.agr.mt.gov/

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

              April 14, 1994, THURSDAY, ILLINOIS FIVE STAR Edition

EDGAR AIMS HEALTH PLAN AT BUSINESSES; COMPANIES COULD POOL INSURANCE COSTS

BYLINE: Tim Novak Illinois State Correspondent

SECTION: NEWS; Pg.

Businesses could band together to reduce their health insurance bills, while
workers would get "no frills" coverage if they lose their jobs, under a plan
proposed Wednesday by Gov.

Edgar's plan is less comprehensive than the national health-care reforms
proposed by President Bill Clinton and his wife Hillary Rodham Clinton, but the
governor said the state shouldn't wait for Congress to act.

"While the debate over health-care reform in Washington drags on, we can take
immediate steps here in Illinois to improve the availability and affordability
of health-care coverage for millions of people," Edgar said at a news conference
in the state Capitol.

Edgar stressed that his health-care plan, which he promised five weeks ago,
would not create a new bureaucracy to oversee health insurance nor cost
taxpayers any money.

Edgar's plan would create a voluntary system so businesses could join to buy
health insurance for their workers.

By forming a larger pool of employees, Edgar said companies might be able to
lower their health insurance costs.

State law currently bans businesses from joining to obtain health insurance for
their workers.

"The ability of employers of all sizes to form insurance pools opens up the
market to health care at more reasonable costs, particularly for small
businesses, their workers and dependents," the governor said.

Many small businesses throughout the country do not offer their employees health
insurance because they can't afford it.

By forming pools with other companies,
Edgar said, small businesses might find they could afford to provide health
insurance.

Edgar's plan, unlike the Clinton proposal, would not force businesses to provide
health insurance to anyone.

Low-cost health insurance would be available to any worker who loses a job,
Edgar said.

Under Edgar's plan, those workers could buy a "no-frills" policy
that would limit future employers from imposing new waiting periods for a
pre-existing ailment.

LOAD-DATE: April 15, 1994

LANGUAGE: English

                  Copyright 1994 St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Inc.

                              199 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                              The Bismarck Tribune

                             June 19, 2007 Tuesday

BYLINE: SARA KINCAID Bismarck Tribune

SECTION: NEWS; Pg.

1b

LENGTH: 523 words


Mandan public schools will move to a fully-funded health insurance plan in
October.

Premiums will
go up 26 percent, and Blue Cross Blue Shield will decide the deductible instead
of the district, business manager Joe Lukach said.

Currently, the district has a self-funded health plan administered by Blue Cross
Blue Shield with a $1,000 deductible.

The plan, however, cannot sustain itself.

Each year the district puts money from its general fund into the health
insurance account.

Over the past three years, it has put $750,000 of general
fund money into the health insurance account.

The health insurance committee compared the cost of a self-funded and fully
funded health plan in 2005-06, and the fully funded plan would have saved the
district money, board member Tim Tausend said.

The health insurance committee
recommended the change.

Health insurance costs affected negotiations with the Mandan Education
Association.

The final agreement, which was approved at a special meeting June
13, included a salary package that has the teachers paying for half of the
health insurance increase through payroll deductions.

The agreement was approved after minor changes to wording, board member and
negotiation team member Kirsten Baesler said.

The financial package is the same
as what was agreed to at a negotiation meeting June 7, she said.

Teachers will receive $2,595,723 in additional money to pay for salaries, health
insurance, Teachers Fund For Retirement increases and co-curricular costs.

The
salary for a first-year teacher with a bachelor's degree will be $26,825 in
2007-08 and $28,865 in 2008-09, according to the schedule in the negotiated
agreement.

The 2006-07 base salary for a first-year teacher with a bachelor's
degree is $25,600.

The board also considered changes to the plans for the new middle school during
an update.

A curtain separating part of the cafeteria will become a wall so that
sports activities do not disturb fine arts activities, and the board decided it
wants a 10-foot asphalt bike path instead of one made of concrete or a five-foot
concrete sidewalk.

The city is requiring the bike path or a side walk along
Sunset Drive.

It also approved some electrical changes associated with the wall,
the addition of automatic flushing fixtures for the rest rooms in the library so
that they match the fixtures in the rest of the school and five security
cameras.

Wet weather has delayed work at the middle school site, which was ahead of
schedule, but it caused work to progress at the high school on the air
conditioning project.

That project is about $23,000 overbudget.

It will be
funded from the interest earned on the bonds.

In other board news, the district is hiring for a principal for Fort Lincoln
Elementary School because Principal Owen Stockdill will take the place of
Shirley Reed at Lewis and Clark Elementary School.

The deadline for applications
is Friday, and so far nine people have applied.

Board member Tom Arenz will
serve on the interviewing committee.

LOAD-DATE: June 19, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved

                               India Pharma News

                     September 20, 2013 Friday 6:30 AM EST

Core Documents: How Health Care Reform Affects Section 125 Premium Only
Cafeteria Plans January 1, 2014

LENGTH: 694  words


New Delhi, Sept. 20 -- Today, Core Documents, the leading provider of affordable
Section 125 Cafeteria Plan Documents to small employers, published new
information on How Health Care Reform Affects Section 125 Premium Only Plans
January 1, 2014.

The good news is Core Documents expects Section 125 Premium
Only Plans to remain a viable employer and employee tax favored program after
Healthcare Reform, and for years to come, with only minor changes described
below.

A Section 125 Premium Only Plan (POP) is an essential benefit that still allows
employees to pay their portion of health insurance, and other ancillary
insurance premium on a pretax basis.

Employees save 22% to 40% of premium cost
in reduced tax liability, depending on their tax bracket.

Employers also save
between 7.65% and 10% by eliminating matching federal unemployment (FUTA) and
social security (FICA) taxes and possibly workers' compensation cost.

It really
is a "win-win" solution with no downside for the employer.

Both the employer and
employee save money.

A plan document and summary plan description is required by
the IRS and Department of Labor before pretax deductions are taken.

This is a
benefit that actually reduces employer overhead and employee benefit cost.

Core
Documents provides employers with affordable ACA compliant Section 125 Premium
Only Plan Documents at www.Core125.com.

New Code Excludes (Only) Individual Health Coverage from a State Exchange

Under current Internal Revenue Code (Code), the term "qualified benefit" is
broadly defined to cover most group and individual insurance premium such as
medical, dental, vision, ancillary, and group term life insurance.

Beginning
January 1, 2014 the Affordable Care Act (ACA) adds a new section 125(f)(3) to
the Code that excludes (only) individual insurance premium offered through a
State Exchange.

All other types of individual health insurance premium outside
the State Exchange program can still be deducted using a Section 125 Premium
Only Plan.

The ACA provides federal funds for States to establish and administer two types
of Exchanges - American Health Benefit Exchanges or Individual Insurance
Exchanges, and Small Business Health Option Program Exchanges or SHOP Exchanges.

Individual Insurance Exchanges will help people purchase individual health
insurance coverage, and SHOP Exchanges will help qualified employers purchase
group health insurance coverage.

State Exchanges will only sell qualified health insurance plans.

Qualified means
health insurance plans that cover essential health benefits, meet specific
cost-sharing rules, and satisfy actuarial requirements.

Plan design options will
include the bronze, silver, gold, platinum, and a catastrophic plan for those
under age 30 to make it easier to compare benefits and cost.

The reason individual health insurance offered through a State Exchange is being
excluded as a qualified benefit under Section 125 is because the premium is
subsidized by the government.

To deduct a federally subsidized premium through a
Section 125 Plan would constitute what the IRS refers to as "double-dipping".

So
only subsidized individual insurance premium offered through the State Exchange
will be excluded.

New Code Allows Group SHOP Exchange Insurance Premium Deductions via Section 125
POP

The new section 125(f)(3) Code eliminating (only) individual health insurance
offered through a State Exchange does provide an exception - the new rules do
not apply to employer group health insurance plans offered from a SHOP Exchange.

New Code section 125(f)(3)(B) provides the exception that allows qualified
employers to use a Section 125 Premium Only Plan to pretax group health
insurance premium purchased from a SHOP Exchange.

Core Documents has been providing Section 125 Cafeteria Plan Documents starting
at only $99 since 1997.

See more information about Section 125 Premium Only
Plans, Health FSA Plans, and Dependent Care FSA plans at www.CoreDocuments.com,
or call us toll free at 1-888-755-3373.

Qualified benefit consultants are
standing by to answer all your questions and help you design an affordable ACA
compliant plan document specifically for your company.

LOAD-DATE: September 21, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Web Publication

                              All Rights Reserved

                              201 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                                Legal News Line

                            August 3, 2011 Wednesday

Mass.

AG obtains $2.4M judgment

BYLINE: Bryan Cohen

LENGTH: 446 words


BOSTON (Legal Newsline) - Massachusetts Attorney General Martha Coakley
announced a $2.4 million civil judgment Tuesday against two companies for
alleged fraudulent marketing and selling a discount health plan as health
insurance.

The judgment against Consumer Health Benefit Association and National
Benefits Consultants, LLC orders restitution for consumers and preventive
measures to ensure future compliance with the law.

The companies are ordered to
pay consumers in Massachusetts $586,960.95 in restitution and to pay the state
$1,780,000 in civil penalties and $99,000 in attorneys' fees.

The judgment
permanently prohibits the defendants from representing a discount health plan or
insurance as enabling a state resident to meet the state health insurance
coverage mandate when the product does not meet the requisite standard,
marketing or selling as health insurance a product that is not a health benefit
plan and violating regulations issued by Coakley governing discount health plans
and discount health plan organizations.

"Massachusetts residents are generally
required to have health insurance and are afforded a wide range of coverage
options to satisfy their individual needs.

It is particularly important that
companies offering discount health plans clearly disclose what their plans do
and do not offer," Coakley said.

"We will continue to vigorously pursue
companies if they misrepresent discount plans as health insurance in
Massachusetts."

According to a complaint filed in October 2009 against CHBA,
NBC, Guarantee Trust Life Insurance Company and Vantage America Solutions, Inc.,
the defendants allegedly engaged in deceptive and unfair sales of a discount
health plan to consumers using multiple tactics and represented the discount
health plan as health insurance and as sufficient to satisfy the state law
requiring individuals to have health insurance.

CHBA and NBC have filed for
bankruptcy in Florida, which will necessarily affect the availability of funds
to pay the judgment.

Coakley's lawsuit against Vantage America Solutions, Inc.
and Guarantee Trust Life Insurance Company is ongoing.

Discount health plans
claim to offer consumers discounts for specific health care services or products
from certain providers in exchange for some form of fee.

Under a discount health
plan, the plan member should receive a discount but is obligated to make all
payments for provided services.

Discount health plans are not themselves
insurance products and are not regulated by the Massachusetts Division of
Insurance, Coakley says.

These plans are not actually health insurance and do
not meet the requirement under state law to have health insurance.

LOAD-DATE: August 8, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                                US Official News

                             July 19, 2016 Tuesday

Insurance Commissioner Advises Consumers to be Wary of Limited Benefit Plans,
Exercise Caution When Shopping for Health Insurance

LENGTH: 472  words

DATELINE: New York



 Harrisburg: Pennsylvania Department of Insurance has issued the following news
release:



   Insurance Commissioner Teresa Miller today issued a consumer alert advising
consumers to be cautious and understand the policy before purchasing a health
insurance plan.

The Affordable Care Act created a federally-run health insurance marketplace
located at www.Healthcare.gov, and subsidies are only available through the
federal marketplace.

Health insurance plans can still be purchased "off-marketplace."

These plans
may advertise coverage at a lower rate, but they are not required to meet the
same coverage standards as marketplace plans and may provide a more limited
scope of benefits.

Websites like healthcare.com  may resemble the federal
marketplace, but these are off-marketplace plans and are not eligible for
subsidies.

In addition, these plans may not protect you from tax penalties for
not having minimum essential coverage.

"Providing tools to consumers that can help them make informed and empowered
decisions about their health insurance has been a priority of the Insurance
Department," said Commissioner Miller.

"Off-marketplace products are still
available, and like any other insurance policy, consumers need to understand
these products and the coverage they offer before making a purchase."

Off-marketplace plans may advertise coverage at a lower rate than plans
available through the federal marketplace, but these plans do not always offer
the same level of coverage for routine medical visits, preventive care, and
diagnostic testing.

These plans are not required to provide coverage for
pre-existing conditions, meaning you may have to pay for services related to
pre-existing conditions out-of-pocket.

In addition, many of these plans have pre-designated reimbursement rates for
types of services.

For example, you could be reimbursed $200 for a trip to the
emergency room and would be responsible for any remaining or extra charges.

Commissioner Miller urged consumers to consider the following questions when
shopping for a health insurance plan, including:



     Does the plan provide coverage for preventive, diagnostic, and other
routine services?

Are your doctors in the plan's provider network?

Does the plan meet minimum essential coverage requirements?

Will you
receive a 1095 tax form?

"If your health insurance plan does not meet minimum essential coverage
standards outlined in the Affordable Care Act, you may face a tax penalty," said
Commissioner Miller.

"Review your policy and understand its specifics so you can
answer these questions.

If you're unsure about anything, talk to your agent or
contact the Insurance Department's Bureau of Consumer Services."

In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                         Brattleboro Reformer (Vermont)

                           November 8, 2007 Thursday

Catamount Health Insurance Information

BYLINE: Bellows Falls Town Crier

SECTION: LOCAL

LENGTH: 265 words


Sojourns Community Health Clinic will offer free informational sessions about
the Catamount Health Insurance Plan on Thursday, Nov. 15 at 7 p.m.

At the event, a representative from Windham County will present information
about Catamount, and will then be available to answer questions about Catamount
and all the State-run insurance products and premium assistance programs.

These
informational sessions will take place at Sojourns on Route 5 in Westminster,
Vt.

The Catamount Health Plan is a new health insurance plan designed to offer
comprehensive benefits with very low out-of-pocket co-pays and other expenses.

Financial assistance with the Catamount Health Plan is also available through
premium assistance to individuals and families.

Catamount Health is intended for half of the state's estimated 65,000 uninsured
who don't qualify for other state-subsidized health insurance plans.

This plan
is a part of the State of Vermont's initiative to develop several programs to
improve the affordability of health insurance so that all Vermonters may have
access to coverage.

Catamount Health policies will be offered by two private
insurance companies: Blue Cross Blue Shield of Vermont and MVP Health Plan.

Enrollment opened Oct. 1, with coverage expected to start Nov. 1.

Come learn more about the insurance options that are available to you through
the State of Vermont.

For more information about these events, please contact Diana Venman at
Sojourns: (802) 722-4023.

March 21, 2013

                            Celtic Insurance Company

                             233 South Wacker Drive
                                 Chicago 60606
                            United States of America

* * * * * * * * * * DESCRIPTION * * * * * * * * * *


COMPANY OVERVIEW

   Celtic Insurance Company (Celtic) is a privately held insurance service
provider in the US.

The company offers a wide range of insurance products and
services across the US health insurance industry for individuals, families,
children and the self employed.

Its product offering comprises various low-cost
individual health insurance plans and medical insurance plans.

Moreover, the
company also offers post-employment benefits through its conversion coverage
program.

Furthermore, it also offers online quote and claim management service
through its website.

It serves more than 30,000 policyholders nationwide.

The
company operates as a subsidiary of Centene Corporation.

Celtic is headquartered
in Chicago, Illinois, the US.

BUSINESS DESCRIPTION

   Celtic Insurance Company is one of the leading specialty health insurance
companies in the US health insurance sector.

The company operates as a
subsidiary of Centene Corporation since 2008.

The company offers a broad array
of health insurance products covering a wide range of customers from
individuals, families, children and the self employed.

The company's diversified
insurance product offering includes the coverage's for over 30,000 policyholders
in the country.

The health insurance solutions offered by the company include low cost
individual health insurance products for people of different age group, family
health insurance products, kids health plan and of the self employed people.

The
individual health insurance plans offered by the company includes economical
basic health coverage plan (Celtic Basic), comprehensive health plan (CeltiCare,
CeltiCare II and CeltiCare Preferred), Health Savings Account (HAS) qualified
health plan (CelticSaver HSA), short term medical insurance (Celtic Short-Term),
and student health insurance (Celtic PostGrad).

The medical insurance products offered by the company includes stand-alone
guarantee-issue medical conversion program to the self-funded employer groups,
stop-loss and fully-insured group carriers, managed care plans, and HMO
reinsurers across the 49 states in the US.

In addition, the company also offers a service: Locate a doctor or hospital
wherein it contracts with Preferred Provider Organizations (PPOs) to make use of
their network of health care providers and hospitals for its PPO health benefit
plans.

Celtic markets, sells and distributes its insurance products online and
through its direct sales agents all over the country.

Its product offering
comprises health insurance, medical insurance, and accident insurance products.

It has the license to operate in the 49 states of US including Alabama, Alaska,
Arkansas, Arizona, California, Connecticut, Colorado, Delaware, Florida,
Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Louisiana, Maryland, Michigan,
Mississippi, Missouri, Nebraska, New Hampshire, New Mexico, Nevada, North
Carolina, Ohio, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, South Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee,
Texas, Virgina, Washington D.C., West Virginia, Wisconsin and Wyoming.

In June 2011, A.M. Best has upgraded the issuer credit rating (ICR) of Celtic
Insurance Company from "bbb" to "bbb+" and accredited the financial strength
rating of B++ (Good) with stable outlook.

                        The Patriot Ledger (Quincy, MA)

                           November 12, 2005 Saturday
                                  ROP Edition

COMMENTARY;
We all pay for those without health insurance

BYLINE: State Rep. Ron Mariano

SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg.

7

LENGTH: 926 words


REP. RON MARIANO

The House of Representatives, under the leadership of Speaker Sal DiMasi, has
put forth an ambitious plan to provide health insurance for 95 percent of our
residents within three years.

This groundbreaking legislation significantly
expands coverage for the poor and encourages personal responsibility, by
requiring individuals to buy insurance if there is an affordable plan available
to them.

It is an attempt to bring individuals, business, and the state together
as partners in a comprehensive plan to solve the problem of the uninsured.

I
served as Chairman of the Committee on Insurance for four years, and have worked
on countless other subcommittees and task forces that have studied our health
care problems.

After much investigation, it is apparent that our Uncompensated Care Pool, the
funding mechanism by which we pay health care providers for services delivered
to the uninsured, is one of our most significant problems.

The commonwealth had
spent more than $750 million in the past two state budgets to fund this free
care pool.

Additionally, we required businesses that already provided insurance
to their employees, and insurance companies themselves, to pay $160 million into
this pool.

All of this money was being spent on people who were eligible but not
enrolled in Medicaid, or on people who were not offered health insurance through
their employer, or who simply chose not to purchase it.

Make no mistake about
it, there is no free care; we all pay for this coverage.

Exacerbating this
problem is the fact that much of this care was provided in the most expensive
setting available, a hospital emergency room.

The House plan uses a tiered
approach to reduce the number of residents seeking care from the Uncompensated
Care Pool by proposing the following solutions: expand access to cover more
people in the most cost-effective manner; enable insurers to provide more
affordable products; and encourage responsible consumer behavior.

Under the
legislation, the state would provide health insurance to 100,000 low-income
children, parents, and other adults.

Additionally, the state would offer
subsidies with sliding scale premiums for nearly 150,000 people through the new
Commonwealth Care Health Insurance Program.

The proposal relies on leveraged
federal funds, employer contributions, and redistributed Uncompensated Care Pool
dollars to expand coverage to roughly 585,000 uninsured residents.

The House
plan would also use funds from the state's 1998 tobacco settlement to help pay
for new costs to the state.

The House plan attempts to spread the cost of health
care services for the uninsured to businesses that do not offer health insurance
and whose employees, in many cases, are receiving health services through the
free care pool, and also to individuals that have chosen not to participate in
the current system and who still use the free care pool.

It is a question of
equality and fairness.

Why should companies that offer health insurance to their
employees also be burdened with paying the health care costs of employees of
another company that chooses not to offer insurance?

The plan exempts very small
businesses that have 10 employees or less, as well as businesses that spend more
than 7 percent of their payroll on health insurance.

Individuals employed by
companies that do not offer health insurance or are otherwise uninsured would
now be required to purchase health insurance on their own, but only when an
affordable policy is available in the market.

Paying for the uninsured is a
problem for which we all must be responsible.

Adding a new requirement on
businesses and individuals without also making changes to our expensive health
insurance market would be unfair, which is why the House plan also takes steps
to make it easier and less expensive to buy health insurance.

The new Health
Insurance Connector will act as a one-stop shopping center, selling affordable,
pre-approved health plans to businesses and individuals alike.

By allowing the
Connector to sell a much wider range of health insurance plans than is currently
available, we give companies the ability to tailor their policies to the needs
of their employees.

The Connector reduces administrative burdens on small
businesses, facilitates portability of plans, and allows part-time and seasonal
workers to combine contributions from multiple employers.

Additionally, all
policies sold through the Connector can be purchased with pre-tax dollars,
maximizing consumer buying power.

For those lower-income individuals who do not
qualify for coverage under our expanded Medicaid program, and who are unable to
purchase health insurance on their own, the state will help pay the monthly
premiums on a sliding scale, but only to the extent that is absolutely
necessary.

In addition to the reforms outlined above, the bill will also enable
insurers to offer more affordable products by merging the non-group and
small-group markets, permit HMOs to offer Health Savings Accounts, place a
moratorium on additional health insurance mandates, permit children to stay on
their parents' policies for two years beyond loss of dependent status, and
create specialized low-cost products for 19 to 26-year-olds.

By taking bold and
innovative steps, the House has created a comprehensive plan that should provide
health insurance coverage for 95 percent of Massachusetts residents within three
years.

The opportunity has never been greater to provide real reform for the
people of our state.

LOAD-DATE: November 21, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                       Copyright 2005 The Patriot Ledger
