Hospitality Industry Health Insurance Trust Offers New, Improved Plans With
Extended PPO Network

LENGTH: 270  words


Sept. 10 -- US-based Hospitality Industry Health Insurance Trust issued the
following news release:

The Hospitality Industry Health Insurance Trust (H.I.H.I.T.

), who specializes in
providing health insurance to restaurant and hotel employers, recently announced
their new and improved plans.

These new plans include an extended PPO network,
and employer flexibility for contribution and participation.

With healthcare reform affecting so many hotels and restaurants, these new plans
with industry specific flexibility will be essential for the hospitality to get
through the healthcare reform changes unscathed.

The performance-based health plan (PPO) is from a H.I.H.I.T.

This brand new plan aims to drive employee engagement in healthy
behavior and better health care choices by offering preferred pricing for higher
performing providers.

Because H.I.H.I.T.

solely serves the hospitality industry, all their resources
and knowledge are abundant and thorough.

They understand that health insurance
for this industry is unlike any other, and H.I.H.I.T.

strives to be the go-to
source for healthcare related topics and healthcare reform.

Plus, each client's plan is reviewed in detail to ensure it's the
best fit for their unique situation.

H.I.H.I.T decided to employ these new plans with the mission to help companies
in the restaurant and lodging industry to save time and be compliant, while
providing the absolute best health insurance to employees.

                              264 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                       Telegram & Gazette (Massachusetts)

                      May 14, 2002 Tuesday, FINAL EDITION

City workers able to keep care provider;
 Health plan changes made

BYLINE: Nick Kotsopoulos; TELEGRAM & GAZETTE STAFF

SECTION: LOCAL NEWS; Pg.

B1

LENGTH: 675 words

DATELINE: WORCESTER



- Municipal employees have won their fight to retain Blue Cross and Blue Shield
as one of their health insurance providers.

However, there will be some changes to their plans.

Janice Borg Silverman, the city's director of human resources, said the city
intends to move forward with a plan that will include Blue Cross and Fallon
Community Health Plan as the health insurance providers for active and retired
municipal employees.

She said the plan will result in a $10.2 million increase in the city's health
insurance costs for the fiscal year that begins July 1.

That is $900,000 less
than what the health insurance increase would have been had there been a
''status quo enrollment'' with no plan design changes.

For the current fiscal year, the city's health insurance costs are expected to
reach about $35 million.

City officials had originally hoped to cap the health insurance increase for
next year at $4 million to $4.5 million and wanted to drop Blue Cross as a
health insurance provider.

But that was adamantly opposed by the employee unions
and retirees.

''We have had limited success in plan design changes, and no success with
employee contribution changes,'' Ms. Silverman wrote in a report to City Manager
Thomas R. Hoover.

The plan changes include the following:

Blue Choice will have a $5 office visit co-payment, from the current $3
co-payment, and emergency room visits will cost $50.

The current co-payment for
emergency room visits is $25.

Medex will have a new $250 annual deductible for retail prescription drugs.

Retirees covered under that program currently have a $35 per quarter deductible.

The co-payment for mail-away prescription drugs will be $10 for generic and $20
for name brand, both for 90-day supplies.

That is an increase from the current
$2 co-payment for generic and $15 for name brand drugs.

There will be no changes to the Fallon plan for active employees and qualified
retirees, the Fallon Senior Plan, or the Blue Cross Master Medical Plan, Ms.
Silverman said.

She added, however, the city has concerns with its existing Blue Care 65 Plan --
a Medicare supplement plan in which more than 600 retirees are enrolled.

She
said there has been significant provider disruption lately because of the
termination of the contract with physicians at Chadwick Medical Associates.

The city has also been notified of the intention of UMass Memorial Healthcare to
terminate its contract with Blue Care 65 in January.

As a result, Ms. Silverman
said, the city has explored options to replace Blue Care 65.

''We have found what we believe to be a far richer plan in terms of benefits and
service co-payments in the Managed Blue for Seniors Plan,'' Ms. Silverman said.

''This plan, however, is more expensive than the existing Blue Care 65 Plan, and
is priced accordingly.''

Instead of footing the bill for 84 percent ($193.73) of the monthly Blue Care 65
premium, the city will be paying 75 percent ($191.90) of monthly premium for
Managed Blue for Seniors.

Ms. Silverman said she believes the increased cost to retirees will be more than
offset by the enhanced benefits they will receive under the new plan.

The open enrollment period for employees and retirees to sign up for health
insurance will begin Monday and run through June 7.

Ms. Silverman said open
enrollment notices will be mailed to all employees and retirees on Friday.

She
said the notices will include additional information on plan changes, new
premiums and educational seminars.

But because no
agreement could be reached between the city and the employee unions on health
insurance carriers, it was delayed.

Because of that delay, the city will be unable to implement the new premiums in
June.

As a result, the city will be stopping premium deductions from June
paychecks, and deducting an additional one-half premium during July and August
in order to make up that deficit, Ms. Silverman said.

LOAD-DATE: May 19, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

               Copyright 2002 Worcester Telegram & Gazette, Inc.

                              265 of 999 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                             March 20, 2015 Friday

New York: New Student Health Insurance Plan and Policy Introduced

LENGTH: 824  words

DATELINE: Albany


Syracuse University, The State of New York has issued the following News
release:

In accordance with the federal Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act of
2010 (ACA), Syracuse University will be offering a new student health insurance
plan as of Aug. 1.

The plan offering coincides with a revised University
policy--to be phased in over the next two years--requiring that all full-time
students carry some form of ACA-compliant health insurance.

The policy change brings Syracuse in line with policies already in place at
nearly every other private college and university in the United States.

The decision, based on the recommendations of the University's Student Health
Insurance Advisory Committee, is designed to ensure students have the health
coverage vital to their well-being and to meet the requirements of the new
health care reforms.

"Our current health insurance plan was unsustainable as it was," says Senior
Vice President and Dean of Student Affairs Rebecca Reed Kantrowitz.

"To provide
all students with access to an affordable, ACA-compliant plan, we needed to
assess different options to ensure no student was left underinsured and at risk
of jeopardizing their education or financial stability.

The advisory committee, which spent 18 months assessing the impact of health
care reform on the University's existing program and exploring student health
insurance options, recommended Syracuse adopt this higher education best
practice.

Doing so will ensure full-time students have adequate, ACA-compliant
health insurance during their time at Syracuse.

Under the ACA, students must
maintain health insurance or pay a penalty to the federal government.

While all students can access health care services through University Health
Services, Syracuse University has long encouraged students to maintain health
insurance coverage for medical emergencies and hospitalization.

Nevertheless, a
survey conducted by the University indicates that while the vast majority of
students already carry appropriate coverage, some students still come to campus
either uninsured or underinsured.

With this new policy, the University wants to
make sure that students are prepared for any medical situation and their
continued well-being and success while at Syracuse is the priority.

Starting August 1, the plan will be available to all students.

However in the
2015-16 academic year only full-time students new to the University--including
undergraduate, graduate and law, along with all full-time international students
and all graduate Fellows, will be affected by the requirement.

Those students
will be required to demonstrate proof of appropriate existing coverage prior to
registration for classes or adopt the student health insurance plan through
Aetna Student Health.

The premium for this improved plan is less than $2,000 a
year--a significant reduction from what's currently available through the
federal government's health exchange marketplace, as well as the University's
current plan, which is being discontinued.

Beginning in the fall of 2016, all full-time, matriculated students will be
required to demonstrate proof of appropriate health insurance coverage upon
registering for classes.

This can include insurance provided through a parent's
family plan, through an employer, health care exchange or other source.

Those
without qualifying coverage will be required to enroll in the University's
student health insurance plan.

Director of Health Services Ben Domingo, co-chair of the advisory committee,
says when uninsured or inadequately insured students face health concerns or
financial barriers to accessing health care services off campus, their ability
to pursue their education is greatly impacted.

"We all know the kind of stress a serious medical event can place on a student
and his or her family," Domingo says.

"We have an obligation to ensure our
students are healthy when they arrive on campus and that they continue to have
appropriate access to emergency care and specialty care when needed throughout
their years in Syracuse."

Karen Morrissey, executive director of Human Resources Operations and co-chair
of the advisory committee, says there have been students in the past who have
delayed seeking proper medical treatment because they did not have adequate
insurance coverage.

"Students' well-being is our top priority, and we want to be
sure no student is ever faced with a situation where he or she must assume an
added financial burden because of an unexpected medical event," Morrissey says.

To assist students with these changes and to provide more details on the new
student health insurance plan and proof of insurance requirement, informational
sessions are scheduled for Tuesday, April 14, from 6-7 p.m. and Wednesday, April
15, from 5:30-6:30 p.m. in Grant Auditorium.

In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

                              India Insurance News

                        May 30, 2017 Tuesday 6:30 AM EST

New AgileHealthInsurance.com Technology Helps Consumers Keep Short-Term Health
Insurance when Transitions Last Longer Than Expected

LENGTH: 542  words


May 30 -- Short-term health insurance plays a vital role for consumers going
through transitions, and AgileHealthInsurance.com has just made it easier for
people to keep short-term health coverage when it's needed for longer than
expected.

For more than 30 years, people have relied on short-term health
insurance in a range of situations, including workers who are in between jobs,
children and spouses no longer eligible under an employer-sponsored plan, and
college graduates and students who need coverage for the summer.

When transitions take longer than expected or exceed the term of the initial
short-term plan, consumers must reapply for new short-term coverage.

Previously,
this process was burdensome to consumers, requiring them to navigate complex
state regulations and time-consuming insurance company-specific applications.

However, AgileHealthInsurance.com has streamlined the application process so
consumers can select the same plan as their current one or apply for a different
plan, all online and in just a few minutes.

Agile's innovative process is
designed to help consumers avoid lapses in coverage, as well as overlapping
premiums with multiple plans and offers a hassle-free experience for consumers.

"Sometimes it's hard to predict how low long you'll need short-term health
insurance coverage, and a lapse of creditable health insurance coverage is a
serious concern for consumers," said Bruce Telkamp, founder and CEO of
AgileHealthInsurance.com.

"AgileHealthInsurance.com's proprietary technology has
simplified the shopping, application and now the reapplication process so
consumers have access to the short-term health plan they need and for as long as
they need it.

We are proud to be the leader in bringing affordable health
insurance solutions to consumers online."

Despite its affordable premiums, short-term coverage includes major medical
benefits, such as doctor and specialist visits, hospitalization, emergency care
and drug discounts.

Most short-term plans include broad networks or no
in-network requirement so people can see providers anywhere in the country.

Eligibility requirements and flexibility in benefits contribute to the cost
savings realized by consumers.

These plans are not for everyone, but answering
five to seven questions about your health condition will tell you if you
qualify.

If short-term coverage is needed for less than three consecutive months
within a year, enrollees are not subject to the "shared responsibility tax"
under the Affordable Care Act.

Short-term health insurance is considered "creditable coverage" under the Health
Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA), which is very important
when you are transitioning from one group plan to another, such as an
employer-based plan.

Under federal law, if you have a gap in insurance coverage
longer than 63 days, your subsequent employer-based plan can impose a wait
period of several months before you will be insured for these conditions.

That
is why it's important to have continuous health coverage under a "creditable"
plan, such as short-term health insurance.

To learn more about term health insurance, visit AgileHealthInsurance's Learning
Center at www.AgileHealthInsurance.com.

Source: AgileHealthInsurance.com

LOAD-DATE: May 31, 2017

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Web Publication

                              All Rights Reserved

                              269 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                         Spokesman Review (Spokane, WA)

                            January 22, 2012 Sunday
                                  Main Edition

HEALTH PLANS CAN BE TAILORED

BYLINE: Roger Stark Special to The Spokesman-Review

SECTION: B; Pg.

9

LENGTH: 624 words


Health insurance premiums have been increasing much faster than the cost of
living.

A new ruling from the federal government has the ability to lower these
insurance premium costs.

The Department of Health and Human Services recently announced that states could
determine the cost and scope of health coverage offered in the new federally
mandated state insurance exchanges.

This is potentially great news and a
cost-saver for Washingtonians who purchase health insurance in the individual or
small-group market.

State-based insurance exchanges are one of the main features of the new federal
health care reform legislation (the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act,
or PPACA).

Under current law, they must be in place and running by 2014.

Workers
earning up to 400 percent of the federal poverty level ($89,000 per year for a
family of four) who purchase health insurance in the exchanges will be eligible
for taxpayer-financed subsidies to help cover the cost of their insurance.

The PPACA originally gave the federal government the responsibility of
determining the levels of benefit coverage sold within the exchanges.

There
needed to be at least four levels of benefits with a fifth high-deductible plan
for young adults under the age of 30.

After the recent HHS ruling, states now have the responsibility to set these
coverage levels.

States, not the federal government, must determine what benefit
and provider mandates should be included in the various plans offered in the
exchange.

Plans offered outside of the exchange must essentially be identical to
plans offered within the exchange.

The PPACA also mandates that every adult in the country must purchase health
insurance by 2014 or pay a fine or tax.

This individual mandate will be enforced
by the Internal Revenue Service.

Estimates show that approximately 700,000
Washingtonians will be newly insured and will buy their health insurance in the
exchange.

Ultimately up to 1.5 million people in Washington will access their
health insurance through the exchange.

Washington state now has 58 benefit and provider mandates required in every
individual health insurance plan sold in the state.

Studies show that each of
these mandates adds, on average, 0.5 to 1.5 percent to the cost of any given
plan.

The reality is that consumers do not necessarily want or need all of these
mandates.

For example, why should a 26-year-old single man be forced to pay for maternity
coverage?

Why should women be forced to pay for prostate cancer screening?

These
mandates not only increase the cost of insurance but also reduce the choice of
insurance plans for consumers.

This new HHS ruling allows Washington state officials to redesign the entire
list of health insurance plans offered to the public.

Within a few federal
guidelines, the state now has a clean slate to develop an array of affordable
plans that can be tailored to the specific needs of patients - young and old,
men and women, families and single people.

As required by state legislation, Gov.

Chris Gregoire recently appointed an
eight-member independent board to oversee creation of the Washington insurance
exchange.

This board will determine the plans and benefit levels people are
allowed to buy through our state exchange.

The board should act in a nonpartisan fashion and should design a range of
plans, from low-priced catastrophic, high-deductible plans to expensive
full-benefit, first-dollar coverage.

The citizens of Washington state would then
have real choice in how much coverage and how much they must pay for their
health insurance.

Allowing multiple levels of benefit plans would hold costs
down for patients and would also save money for taxpayers who must provide the
subsidies for users of the exchange.

LOAD-DATE: February 27, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

NOTES: Dr. Roger Stark is a retired surgeon and a health care policy analyst at
the Washington Policy Center, a nonpartisan policy research organization in
Washington state.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                    Copyright 2012 Spokane Spokesman-Review

August 3, 2017

                       Takaful Emarat - Insurnace (P.S.C)

                               New Century Tower
                                     DUBAI
                              United Arab Emirates

* * * * * * * * * * DESCRIPTION * * * * * * * * * *

COMPANY OVERVIEW


   Takaful Emarat - Insurnace (P.S.C) (Takaful Emarat) is an Islamic insurance
company.

The company provides a range of takaful insurance products for
individuals and corporate clients.

Its portfolio of products include whole-life
plan, wealth plan, education plan, level term plan, decreasing term plan,
personal accident plan, travel insurance plan, retirement plan, group life plan
and group credit life plan.

Furthermore, the company offers health insurance
products, which comprise individual and group health plans.

Takaful Emarat
distributes its products through a network of brokers, bancassurance channel and
direct sales force in the UAE.

The company reported gross contribution written of AED402.8 million in
FY2015, as compared with AED169.5 million in FY2014.

It recorded net earned
contributions of AED319.9 million in FY2015, as compared with AED98.2 million in
FY2014.

BUSINESS DESCRIPTION:



Takaful Emarat is a provider of takaful insurance products.

The company offers
life and health insurance products for individuals and corporate clients.

It
also provides credit and savings insurance plans.

Takaful Emarat distributes its
products through network of brokers, bancassurance channel and direct sales
force.

The company has its branch offices in Dubai, Abu Dhabi and Sharjah.

Takaful Emarat classifies its business operations into two reportable divisions:
Takaful and Investment.

The company's Takaful division is focused on underwriting takaful products such
as health insurance, life insurance and, credit and savings plans.

It is further
classified into two sub-divisions: Life and Medical.

The Life sub-division
provides life insurance products for individuals and corporates.

The individual
life insurance products include Al Moyassara plan, wealth plan, whole-life plan,
level term plan, education plan, retirement plan, decreasing term plan, and
travel insurance plan.

The corporate life insurance plans offered by the company
consist of group life and group credit life plans.

The Life sub-division
accounted for 13.3% of the division's total revenues in FY2014.

The Medical
sub-division of the company provides health insurance products for individuals
and corporates, including individual health insurance and group health insurance
plans.

The Medical sub-division accounted for 86.7% of the division's total
revenues in FY2015.

In FY2015, the Takaful division reported revenues of
AED377.9 million, accounting for 98.3% of the company's total revenues.

The Investment division of the company focuses on investment and cash management
of its own account.

In FY2015, Investment sub division has not contributed revenue towards the
division's total revenue, where as other sub divisions accounted 100% toward the
division's total revenues.

In FY2015, the Investment division reported revenues
of AED6.7 million, accounting for 1.7% of the company's total revenues.

22

LENGTH: 486  words


The health and well-being of yourself and your family is of the utmost
importance, and like most people you probably don't want to make any compromises
or take any chances when it comes to protecting your health or that of your
loved ones.

Permanent health insurance coverage is an effective way to provide the whole
family with peace of mind and protection, providing access to a wealth of health
services should the need arise.

Some people are lucky in that they get free health insurance coverage through
their employer as a benefit of the job.

However, for those that do not have this
coverage, and for those that want to provide coverage for the whole family, it
is important to look into the range of available plans and start this protective
health coverage as soon as possible.

Nobody knows when illness, disease, or medical emergencies are going to arise,
but with suitable coverage in place you can be sure that your health needs will
be addressed.

Types of Health Insurance Plans; There are a number of different plans available
for those looking for health insurance coverage.

You can opt for an individual
plan if the coverage is just for yourself.

If you have a partner, you can opt
for joint coverage, and if you also have a family you could go for family
coverage.

This often works out cheaper than taking out individual plans for each
member of the household, and ensures that your loved ones are all covered with
the same level of protection.

When looking into taking out permanent health insurance you need to pay careful
attention to what each plan actually covers before you make any commitment.

Some
plans will cover medical needs only, whereas more comprehensive plans will also
cover dental and optical care.

With a comprehensive permanent health insurance
plan you can expect benefits such as:

"Physician care

"Hospital care (as in-patient or out-patient)

"Dental, optical, and aural care

"Prescription benefits

"Surgery and major medical benefits

Insurance Costs vs. Benefits; As with any other type of insurance, the more
comprehensive plans will also cost more in premiums, but at the same time will
also provide a higher degree of protection and peace of mind.

It is very
important to read the policy in full before committing, as many health insurance
plans contain a lot of exclusions.

You may find that you are not covered for certain problems or in certain
situations, and if you have a pre-existing condition you may also find that this
is not covered under the policy.

If you have any concerns about the policy that
you are thinking of taking, you should address these with the insurer before you
make your decision.

Providing that you are happy with the terms and conditions as well as the
benefits and exclusions of the insurance plan, permanent health insurance
coverage will provide you with an affordable and effective way to protect the
health and well being of yourself and your family.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              The Financial Daily

                            January 22, 2013 Tuesday

A Word from Editor

LENGTH: 486  words


The health and well-being of yourself and your family is of the utmost
importance, and like most people you probably don't want to make any compromises
or take any chances when it comes to protecting your health or that of your
loved ones.

Permanent health insurance coverage is an effective way to provide the whole
family with peace of mind and protection, providing access to a wealth of health
services should the need arise.

Some people are lucky in that they get free health insurance coverage through
their employer as a benefit of the job.

However, for those that do not have this
coverage, and for those that want to provide coverage for the whole family, it
is important to look into the range of available plans and start this protective
health coverage as soon as possible.

Nobody knows when illness, disease, or medical emergencies are going to arise,
but with suitable coverage in place you can be sure that your health needs will
be addressed.

Types of Health Insurance Plans; There are a number of different plans available
for those looking for health insurance coverage.

You can opt for an individual
plan if the coverage is just for yourself.

If you have a partner, you can opt
for joint coverage, and if you also have a family you could go for family
coverage.

This often works out cheaper than taking out individual plans for each
member of the household, and ensures that your loved ones are all covered with
the same level of protection.

When looking into taking out permanent health insurance you need to pay careful
attention to what each plan actually covers before you make any commitment.

Some
plans will cover medical needs only, whereas more comprehensive plans will also
cover dental and optical care.

With a comprehensive permanent health insurance
plan you can expect benefits such as:

"Physician care

"Hospital care (as in-patient or out-patient)

"Dental, optical, and aural care

"Prescription benefits

"Surgery and major medical benefits

Insurance Costs vs. Benefits; As with any other type of insurance, the more
comprehensive plans will also cost more in premiums, but at the same time will
also provide a higher degree of protection and peace of mind.

It is very
important to read the policy in full before committing, as many health insurance
plans contain a lot of exclusions.

You may find that you are not covered for certain problems or in certain
situations, and if you have a pre-existing condition you may also find that this
is not covered under the policy.

If you have any concerns about the policy that
you are thinking of taking, you should address these with the insurer before you
make your decision.

Providing that you are happy with the terms and conditions as well as the
benefits and exclusions of the insurance plan, permanent health insurance
coverage will provide you with an affordable and effective way to protect the
health and well being of yourself and your family.

8 Newly Named AHIP Unveils New Health Reform
Initiative

LENGTH: 453 words

DATELINE: Washington


Under the new name "America's Health Insurance Plans," the association formerly
known as AAHP-HIAA unveiled a new, integrated policy initiative aimed at
achieving comprehensive health care reform.

"This is a new way of thinking about how to improve health care," says Karen
Ignagni, president of the Washington-based AHIP.

"The more we work on these
issues, the more we understand that the priorities of quality, access and
affordability are closely interrelated, and that progress in one area can yield
significant results elsewhere."

Ignagni spoke at a press briefing announcing the association's new name.

AHIP is
the new association formed by the merger of the American Association of Health
Plans and the Health Insurance Association of America.

Ignagni says AHIP's new policy initiative represents a first-of-its-kind effort
that links all the elements of health care reform into a comprehensive program.

AHIP, Ignagni says, is not pursuing specific legislation at this time because
legislating is a multiyear effort.

Rather, she says, AHIP wants to discuss the
policy initiative with as many stakeholders as possible to develop partnerships
aimed at achieving reform.

The first component of the new policy is improved quality, Ignagni says, adding
that the nation must invest in quality research and advance evidence-based
medicine.

She says the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality will receive only $303
million in funding during 2004, which is just 1% of the budget of the National
Institutes of Health.

In addition, Ignagni says, research must be made more transparent and accessible
for both providers and consumers.

As for evidence-based medicine, Ignagni notes that AHIP has asked every state
that requires external review of health plan decisions to base those reviews on
evidence-based medicine.

The second component is access, she says, and AHIP believes the uninsured
population must be "disaggregated" so policies can be targeted at the specific
element causing people to be uninsured.

According to the policy initiative, a variety of approaches are needed to reduce
the number of uninsured Americans, including creation of high-risk health pools,
bridge loans to help workers maintain their coverage when they become
unemployed, public programs for those living below the poverty line and tax
incentives for higher income workers who are uninsured.

The third component, Ignagni says, is affordability.

This includes, she says,
legal reform as well as an examination of the impact of mandates on health care
costs.

"This is a new way of thinking about how to improve health care."

--AHIP President Karen Ignagni

LOAD-DATE: March 22, 2004

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                Copyright 2004 The National Underwriter Company

                              274 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                    June 28, 1989, Wednesday, Final Edition

House Bill Conjures Up A 'Phantom' Premium;
Aim Is to Temper Rise in Health Plan Costs

BYLINE: Judith Havemann, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A21; THE FEDERAL PAGE

LENGTH: 447 words


Washington is accustomed to phantom voters, phantom income and phantom
employees, but the House yesterday passed legislation to create a novel member
of the ghost family -- the phantom health insurance premium.

The House bill is designed to keep federal workers from facing a big jump in
health insurance costs next year.

The Senate is considering a similiar measure.

The administration is opposed.

The "phantom" health insurance premium was drafted as a temporary two-year
measure while the troubled government health insurance system undergoes
revision.

The need for such a phantom device arises because Aetna Life Insurance Co.
recently pulled out of the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program.

The government, under law, averages the premiums of six health plans and pays 60
percent of that figure per enrollee.

Aetna was one of the "big six" plans.

Aetna's premiums have been high in comparison to those of some other plans
because it has tended to insure people who incur more medical bills.

The bill, introduced by Rep. William D. Ford (D-Mich.), essentially directs the
government to proceed as if Aetna were still part of the government insurance
system, raising rates by the same average amount as the remaining big five
plans.

Ford said federal workers, their families and retirees who participate in the
federal health insurance program would have to pay $ 600 million more in
premiums next year if action is not taken.

Ford said federal workers face a 15 percent increase in health insurance costs
in any case.

Without the "phantom" health plan, increases might total 32
percent, Ford said.

The Office of Management and Budget opposed the bill, saying it "relies on a
highly artificial 'phantom' premium based on the premium of a no-longer
participating plan."

OMB said the administration will "shortly" propose a premium stabilization
formula without "resorting to the creation of a phantom premium and without
increasing the burden for current .

enrollees."

OMB last year proposed cutting back on government contributions to the health
insurance program as a cost-saving measure.

The administration said the "big
six" contribution formula should be changed because only 30 percent of federal
employees choose the "big six" insurance companies.

More than 400 insurance plans are included in the federal health insurance
system around the world.

Workers in Washington have a choice of about 25 plans.

"This is still a stopgap solution to the federal health insurance mess," Ford
said.

"It is obvious that the federal health insurance program is in need of
major reform."

TYPE: NATIONAL NEWS

                       Copyright 1989 The Washington Post

DEAL TITLE:  Apollo Munich Health Insurance Partners with Indian Overseas Bank
DEAL TYPE:  Partnership
DEAL SUB-TYPE:  Affinity Marketing

ANNOUNCED DATE:  2015-02-19
DEAL IN BRIEF:  Apollo Munich Health Insurance Company Limited (AMHI), a
provider of health, accident, and travel insurance solutions, has partnered with
Indian Overseas Bank to provide specialized health and personal accident
products to Indian Overseas Bank's customers.

Indian Overseas Bank is an Indian
banking products and services provider.

Through the partnership, Indian Overseas
Bank will sell Apollo Munich's products under the 'GO HEALTH with an expert'
campaign across the country in over 3,350 branches of the bank.

Apollo Munich
Health Insurance will offer customized products with sum insured ranging from
INR0.3 million (USD0.004 million) to INR1 million (USD0.01 million) to Indian
Overseas Bank's customers.

PARTICIPANT COMPANIES INFORMATION:  Apollo Munich Health Insurance Company
Limited Target Apollo Munich Health Insurance Company Ltd. (Apollo Munich) is a
health insurance provider.

The company offers a range of health insurance plans
to individuals, families and senior citizens.

Its product portfolio includes
health insurance plans, travel insurance plans and personal accident insurance
plans.

Its service portfolio includes rider services, claims settlement
services, insurance advisory services, health consultation services over phone
and cashless hospitalization services.

The company sells and distributes its
insurance products and services through a network of branch offices,
banassurance channel, insurance advisors, travel agencies and Apollo Hospitals.

Apollo Munich was formerly known as Apollo DKV Insurance Company Limited.

Apollo
Munich is a joint venture between India based Apollo Hospitals Group and Germany
based reinsurance company Munich Re Group.

In FY2015, the company reported premium earned of INR6,558.8
million, representing an increase of 20.7% over FY2014.

INVOLVEMENT TYPE:  Target

plans to individuals, families and senior citizens.

Its product portfolio
includes health insurance plans, travel insurance plans and personal accident
insurance plans.

DEAL TITLE:  Indian Overseas Bank partners with Visa
DEAL TYPE:  Partnership
DEAL SUB-TYPE:  Affinity Marketing
DEAL SUB-TYPE:  Affinity Marketing
DEAL STATUS:  Completed
ANNOUNCED DATE:  2014-01-03
DEAL IN BRIEF:  Indian Overseas Bank (IOB), an Indian provider of personal,
commercial and retail banking, insurance and investment services, has partnered
with Visa, Inc., to launch Connect Card, a new ATM cum debit card that can be
used for e-commerce across the merchant outlets.

Visa is a payments technology
company engaged in the operation of retail electronic payments network based in
the US.

Though all IOB customers have been provided ATM cum debit card, Connect
Card is targeted at the younger generation aged between 10 and 28 years.

IOB
Connect cards can be used at merchant outlets and for online shopping.

PARTICIPANT COMPANIES INFORMATION:  Visa Inc. Target Visa Inc. (Visa) is a
payments technology company.

The company owns, manages and promotes a range of
payment brands including Visa, Visa Electron, PLUS and Interlink, which are
licensed to customers for use in payment programs offered by Visa.

It provides
transaction processing, mobile money services and value-added services to its
clients.

Visa also offers a wide range of branded payments product platforms,
which are used by its clients to develop and offer prepaid, credit, debit, and
cash access programs.

Furthermore, the company offers digital, mobile and
eCommerce platforms.

Its operations are spanned across the globe.

INVOLVEMENT TYPE:  Target

                          November 12, 2014 Wednesday

Colorado: Workshops Offered by Extension: Helping the Public Make Smart Choices
about Health Insurance

LENGTH: 386  words

DATELINE: Denver


County of Larimer, The State of Colorado has issued the following news release:


Fall is the season for health insurance plan enrollment.

You may be like most
people--confused and uncomfortable, when it comes to making decisions about
health insurance coverage.

Do you know that health insurance helps individuals
and families get access to care leading to better health and reduces the risk of
high health care costs?

That's why a team of experts from Colorado State University Extension are
conducting Smart Choice Health Insurance©  Decisions workshops.

These workshops
and materials are research-based to give people tools to make a smart health
insurance decision for themselves and their families
People who attended these workshops leave feeling they can make smarter health
insurance purchase decisions.

Participants learn key health insurance terms; how
to estimate costs for health care and what questions to ask; and how to find
information to choose a health plan.

"Smart Choice is not about pushing you to select any one specific plan," says
Laurel Kubin, County Extension Director.

"It will help you gain a set of skills
so you can choose a plan that best fits your family's needs."

Workshops are
being offered during open enrollment in the fall of 2014.

"Keeping your head above water can be extremely difficult when navigating the
waters of health insurance - whether you've been insured throughout your life or
are faced with selecting coverage for the very first time," says Kubin.

"Smart
Choice helps eliminate the intimidation factor of health insurance decision
making."

Smart Choice Health Insurance© Decisionsworkshops are scheduled for the
following dates and locations.

Friday, November 14, 1:00 - 3:00 p.m., Larimer County Extension Office, 1525
Blue Spruce Drive, Fort Collins
Tuesday, December 2, 5:30 - 7:30 p.m., Old Town Library,  201 Peterson St., Fort
Collins
Thursday, December 4, 2:00 - 4:00 p.m., Larimer County Extension Office, 1525
Blue Spruce Drive, Fort Collins
Monday, December 8, 5:30 - 7:30 p.m., Loveland Library, 300 N. Adams, Loveland
CO

                        The Patriot Ledger (Quincy, MA)

                           February 4, 2006 Saturday
                                  City Edition

Plan calls for health insurance collective bargaining

BYLINE: Rick Collins

SECTION: NEWS; Pg.

21

LENGTH: 263 words


The Patriot Ledger

BRAINTREE - Selectmen are weighing a proposal that would give them the power to
negotiate changes to employee health insurance plans collectively with the
town's employee unions.

The plan, which is being pushed by the town's eight major collective bargaining
groups, would eliminate the current practice of negotiating changes with each
union.

Such a move would mean the town would be able to enact changes to employee
health insurance plans faster and cheaper.

A trade-off is that any changes to health benefits for retirees would be subject
to collective bargaining.

They currently are not.

The cost of health insurance has grown 61 percent from 2001 to 2005, Michael
Milward, a member of the Braintree Firefighters Local 920, told selectmen this
week.

Braintree employees and the town each pay half the cost of the health
insurance.

"We recognize the need to work together as a team with the town," Milward said.

He did not propose any specific changes to the employee health insurance plan.

Carol Chandor, a Boston-based consultant on employee benefits hired by the
unions, said eight Massachusetts communities have adopted the change to
coalition bargaining, which is known as Section 19.

"Employees and town managers understand that health insurance is a budget
buster," she said.

In order to adopt the change, selectmen would have to approve it and 70 percent
of town employees would have to vote in favor of it.

The two sides would then
sign a memorandum of agreement that would guide negotiations.

Any disagreements would be settled through binding arbitration.

29

LENGTH: 806 words


Congress has the opportunity to pass legislation that is so overwhelmingly
popular it gets nearly 90 percent of the electorate's vote, is critically
important to the well-being of 45 million uninsured Americans and is vital to
the financial health of millions of small businesses.

What could be more
important than this?

Passing it seems logical, but special interests have succeeded in killing it in
the past, and once again they are hard at work raising roadblocks and spreading
misconceptions that could thwart the will of the majority.

Voters everywhere
have a simple message on this one: "Congress, I need health insurance.

I deserve
health insurance.

The bill is S. 1955, the Health Insurance Marketplace Modernization and
Affordability Act, which would allow self-employed workers and small-business
employees to band together through a trade or professional association to
negotiate lower health insurance costs, giving them access to the same quality
group health insurance plans currently available to union workers and employees
of large corporations.

Small-business health plans would be able to take advantage of the same
administrative savings and increased negotiating powers as large corporate and
union plans.

Legislation passed the House last year and S. 1955 is expected to
be voted on by the full Senate in the next few weeks.

Why is it so important to pass S. 1955 now?

"It is a huge strain to try to keep my health insurance.

Each year I struggle
with the decision of whether to try to keep the insurance or let it go," she
said.

Her costs continue to rise at the same time that her deductible increases
and her coverage decreases.

Diane's costs have gone up 373 percent over the past
10 years.

Joyce discovered a lump on her
breast but cannot get it checked out or diagnosed because she has no health
insurance.

She cannot afford the treatment without health insurance and is
afraid that she will not be able to get health insurance if the lump is
cancerous.

Finally, Debbie Flood of Melron Corp. in Schofield, Wis., has experienced
skyrocketing costs in providing health insurance for her employees.

She said
that unquestionably it is an obstacle to future reinvestment in the business.

Melron has experienced 30- to 33-percent increases in premiums in the past two
years.

Multiply those stories by tens of millions and you get the picture, yet a few
healthcare interests are complaining that the legislation would preempt state
health-insurance mandates.

Not surprisingly, many of the interest groups
lobbying against the bill represent the very health providers who benefit from
mandates.

The fears are simply not justified.

The fact is that if a small-business health plan does not comply with a state's
coverage mandates then an additional policy must be offered to association
members that complies either with state law or with the coverage included in one
of the five most populous states' state employee plans (California, New York,
Florida, Illinois or Texas).

States, like the federal government, offer their
employees some of the best insurance plans today.

Another misconception is that small-business plans will "cherry-pick" and cover
only healthy workers.

Specific provisions have been included in the
bill to maintain a level playing field between small-business plans and
state-regulated plans that will prevent "cherry-picking."

They will be subject
to the same Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act, which makes it
illegal to deny coverage to any eligible participant based on the health status
of an individual employee or employer.

Small-business health plans will be regulated by state insurance commissioners,
not the federal government.

Insurers participating in small-business health
plans must be licensed in all states in which association members are enrolled.

As a licensed insurer, the insurer would be regulated by the state insurance
commissioner and subject to all state insurance laws, with the exception of
underwriting and rating rules explicitly addressed in S. 1955.

State oversight
is not neglected, as some may lead you to believe.

Also, small-business plans,
as authorized by S. 1955, must be structured as fully insured insurance
programs.

Trade associations will not be able to self-fund.

When voters want to know what Congress has done for them lately, there is an
answer within reach - affordable and comprehensive healthcare insurance for
small businesses, their employees and their families who are currently without
coverage.

Stevens is president of the National Association of Realtors.

He has been a
Realtor since 1972 and is the senior vice president of NRT Inc. in Vienna, Va.

                                    The Sun

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                August 29, 2012

NB health insurance plan change upheld;
Arbitrator rules union contract was violated, but village retains authority to
choose plan

BYLINE: The Trenton Sun staff

LENGTH: 922  words


An arbitrator in the grievance filed by New Baden's police union has agreed that
the village of New Baden violated the union's collective bargaining agreement in
the way it handled a change in health insurance benefits last year, but not in a
way that requires the village to undo its prior action.

Arbitrator Elaine Frost issued her ruling on August 23, and said that New Baden
police are not entitled to have their health insurance benefits restored, nor to
compensation for additional expenses they may have incurred since the plan was
modified, although the village did not provide sufficient 'consultation'
opportunities for union members to air their opinions on the new plan that was
put in place.

The arbitration hearing took place in May of this year.

"The Employer violated the 'consultation' provision of Article 22 when it failed
to provide timely information to the Union in order to give it an opportunity to
provide it a reasoned basis for consulting with respect to the health insurance
changes that would be made on or about October 3, 2011," Frost wrote in her
decision.

"The Employer is directed to cease all future violations of the
"consultation" provision... At the discretion of the Union, the Union shall be
entitled to consult with the Employer on the health insurance issue.

The
Employer shall consider any Union position(s) offered in any such consultation.

"The Employer is not otherwise found to be in violation of Article 22 by the
manner in which it reached its decision, and by the result it reached, on or
about October 3, 2011, when it adopted new health insurance for Village
employees."

In other words, the village board's decision in October 2011 to modify the
health insurance benefits it offers to its employees will stand.

Village employees, including police, were advised of the potential change on
September 29 during a meeting with village administrator Jimmy Morani, prior to
the village board's meeting on October 3, at which the board approved changes
that increased employees' co-pays for pharmaceuticals and reduced benefits for
medical expenses from 90 percent to 80 percent, among other changes.

Earlier in 2011, the village was advised by its carrier, The Principal Life
Insurance Company, that it would no longer write health insurance policies, and
village administrator Morani contacted a broker to get quotes and consult on
medical plans.

The Principal Life Insurance Company transferred its policies to
United Healthcare, and the village ultimately decided to use that company to
provide for a more seamless transition.

The collective bargaining agreement gives the village the right to choose the
health insurance plan, with the only limit being a cap on the amount of
deductible.

United Healthcare's plan that was most similar to The Principal's
existing coverage would have held costs about static, but the village was able
to save about $10,000 in annual premiums by modifying the plan.

Under the plan
the board selected, the deductible did not increase nor did the total out of
pocket expense.

Prior to its final vote on the new plan, the board discussed the matter at its
committee-at-large meeting on September 19, and that discussion was reported in
The Sun.

Morani then met with employees September 29.

Police officers expressed
their opposition to the proposed plan at that meeting, according to Morani's
testimony as well as that of police union shop steward Angela Wagner and police
sergeant Scott Meinhardt, who was the lead negotiator on the union contract.

Morani then sent an email to police department employees explaining that he had
advised the village board of the officers' opposition and that the board may
take that feedback into consideration before making its final decision.

The
village board approved the modified plan October 3 at its regular monthly
meeting, at which no members of the bargaining unit appeared.

The Union argued that since the collective bargaining agreement specifically
addresses plans changes in the case of exorbitant premium increases and allowed
changes in deductibles, the rest of the plan's features are sacrosanct.

The arbitrator did not agree with the Union's position, since clear language in
the contract gives the employer the right to choose the health insurance plan
and the carrier for that plan, and since both parties agreed to the contract
language.

The arbitrator did conclude that good faith exercise by the employer when
selecting a new health insurance plan is required, and ruled that no
consultation was provided the Union, since it did not provide timely information
about its impending decision, "...the Union was not put on notice in early 2011
when the news reached the village; the Union was not approsed of the actions to
secure a broker to seek out alternative insurance carriers and plans; and it was
not advised when the results of the broker's actions were presented to the
Village Administrator..." according to the arbitrator, "...the actions of the
Employer in its repeated failure to timely disclose information about the need
to replace the health insurance carrier and plan, and the options for that
choice, was nothing short of highhanded."

Nonetheless, the arbitrator provided only window dressing in terms of relief to
the union, the ability to consult with the village on the health insurance
question and to have the village board consider the union's position.

The
village board retains its authority to choose the health insurance plan, subject
to the deductible limits set forth in the contract.

Copyright 2012 The Sun

                               India Pharma News

                     November 30, 2013 Saturday 6:30 AM EST

Experient Health: White House Announces Transition Policy for Canceled Health
Plans

LENGTH: 503  words


New Delhi, Nov. 30 -- The White House announced a transition policy for canceled
health plans, according to Experient Health, the health insurance arm of the
Virginia Farm Bureau.

Experient Health detailed the announcements and explained
its effects in its latest post in a Blog series on health care reform.

The Affordable Care Act (ACA) includes key reforms that create new coverage
standards for health insurance policies, beginning in 2014.

For example,
effective for 2014 plan years, the ACA imposes new modified community rating
standards and requires individual and small group policies to cover a
comprehensive set of benefits.

Over the last few months, millions of Americans received notices informing them
that their health insurance plans are being canceled because they do not comply
with the ACA's reforms.

President Obama has received criticism that these cancellations go against his
assurances that if consumers have a plan that they like, they can keep it.

Responding to pressure from consumers and Congress, on Nov. 14, 2013, President
Obama announced a new transition policy for 2014.

Under the new policy,
individuals and small businesses whose coverage has been canceled (or would be
canceled) because it does not meet the ACA's standards may be able to re-enroll
or stay on their coverage for an additional year.

However, this one-year reprieve may not be available to all consumers.

Because
the insurance market is primarily regulated at the state level, state governors
or insurance commissioners will have to allow for the transition relief.

Also,
health insurance issuers are not required to follow the transition relief and
renew plans, and have expressed concern that the change could disrupt the new
risk pool under the federal and state Health Insurance Marketplaces.

The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) outlined the transition policy
in a letter to state insurance commissioners.

For 2014, health insurance issuers may choose to continue coverage that would
otherwise be terminated or canceled due to the ACA's reforms, and affected
individuals and small business may choose to re-enroll in the coverage.

Under this transitional policy, health insurance coverage in the individual or
small group market that is renewed for a policy year starting between Jan. 1,
2014, and Oct. 1, 2014 (and associated group health plans of small businesses),
will not be considered to be out of compliance with specified ACA reforms if
certain conditions are met.

According to HHS, it will consider the impact of the transition relief in
assessing whether to extend it beyond the specified time frame.

The transitional relief is not available to grandfathered plans because these
plans are not subject to most of the ACA's market reforms.

According to
President Obama, the transition relief is an extension of the grandfathered plan
rules to additional health insurance policies.

B-6

LENGTH: 482 words


The state's new health insurance plan has its limits, but it appears to be a
good start toward common- sense health insurance solutions.

Charlie Crist's administration.

It
is aimed at adults who are uninsured.

And in Florida, there are almost 4 million residents who are uninsured from ages
19 to 64.

The Cover Florida plan takes effect in January for applicants ages 19 to 64 who
have been without health insurance for at least six months, recently unemployed,
for people who have lost employer-sponsored health benefits or are no longer
covered by public health insurance in the last six months.

Six private insurers, including Jacksonville-based BlueCross BlueShield of
Florida, are offering the plans.

UnitedHealthcare also is offering plans
statewide.

Four other insurers are offering plans in counties outside Northeast
Florida.

There are several advantages to the Cover Florida system:

- Pre-existing conditions are covered.

- There are no traditional mandates, though state law does require the plans to
include certain basics.

This allows insurers and consumers more flexibility to
structure plans that fit consumer needs.

- Employers may voluntarily share in the cost of the plan, or they may offer
payroll deduction.

There are two kinds of plans: one that covers preventive medical care and
another that also covers catastrophic and health coverage.

Meanwhile, insurers are looking for ways to provide low-cost coverage for those
who need it.

Blue Cross, like other insurers, has a basic policy that anyone can
purchase.

For instance, for a 40-year-old male, Go Blue premiums for a catastrophic plan
are $106.

The Cover Florida version costs $150.

Cover Florida is a good start and good service for some residents.

The principles are excellent.

Competition among private companies; flexibility,
freed from most government mandates.

VISION OF REFORM

BlueCross BlueShield of Florida suggests that health care reforms should include
five critical elements:

Wellness and prevention.

Give incentives for keeping people healthy rather than
just treating the sick.

New health care delivery.

Promote health care standards and free physicians from
liability, reducing defensive medicine.

Universal coverage.

Insurance works best when risk is spread.

Uninsured too
often wait till illness is far advanced, using emergency rooms for primary care,
the most expensive option.

Spreading risk nationwide would free Florida from its
disproportionate share of caring for seniors.

Personal responsibility.

Smoking was cut in half in one generation.

Similar
lifestyle improvements are needed for good nutrition and exercise.

The Blue Cross model seeks to capitalize on the private market for
health care delivery rather than a single payer government model.

                              282 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                The Berkshire Eagle (Pittsfield, Massachusetts)

                             May 7, 2008 Wednesday

Report: Pittsfield could save $5.6M

BYLINE: By Tony Dobrowolski, Berkshire Eagle Staff

SECTION: HEALTH; Headlines

LENGTH: 776 words


PITTSFIELD -- After exploring several health insurance scenarios over the last
three months, a committee of city officials has found that Pittsfield could have
saved $5.6 million this fiscal year if it had joined the state's insurance pool.

Following those findings, Mayor James M. Ruberto announced he will submit a
petition to the City Council within the next few weeks that would allow
officials to engage in coalition bargaining with Pittsfield's 18 municipal
unions to join the Group Insurance Commission.

The GIC has administered health benefits for state employees and retirees since
1955.

Last year, the Legislature passed the Municipal Partnership Act, which
allows cities and towns to join the GIC as part of the same risk pool, which has
more than 294,000 members.

In order for Pittsfield to join the GIC, all 18 of the city's collective
bargaining units have to agree to the measure by a margin of at least 70 percent
of a vote "weighted" along each union's membership.

The unions normally
negotiate contracts with the city separately, under the process that is known as
collective bargaining.

But the GIC negotiations require the unions to negotiate
with the city as one group, a method known as coalition bargaining.

"There are complications and complexities with the unions themselves to
determine if they want to engage in coalition bargaining," Ruberto said.

"The
first step is the authorization that the two parties are willing to talk."

The heads of nine collective bargaining units were among the 22 people in
attendance Monday night when the health insurance committee's findings were
revealed at a special meeting of the City Council.

Holly A. Taylor of True North Financial Services, the city's health insurance
broker, has told the City Council that the city could initially save millions of
dollars by joining the GIC, but that those savings could dissipate due to the
cost of getting all 18 unions to agree to the plan.

The city would be
required to notify the state by October to have city employees receive GIC
health insurance benefits by July 1, 2009.

The nine-member health insurance committee, which includes four city councilors,
Ruberto, and four city officials, was formed in January to explore the option of
having the city join the GIC.

The committee examined health insurance trends in
Pittsfield over the last 10 years and compared the city and the GIC plans under
various scenarios in a 27-page report.

The committee found the city could have saved $5.6 million in fiscal 2008 by
comparing the total health insurance costs for Pittsfield's employees and
retirees with a GIC cost scenario in which the entire city pool of employees and
retirees was split evenly between health maintenance organization and preferred
provider plans.

The committee believed that scenario was the most likely option
if Pittsfield joined the GIC.

The total fiscal 2008 costs under Pittsfield's current health insurance plan are
$23.4 million, while the total costs under the GIC scenario were $17.8 million.

Ward 5 Councilor Jonathan N. Lothrop, who chaired the committee, said joining
the GIC would keep health insurance costs down.

Taylor told an employee
commission last week that Pittsfield's health insurance costs are scheduled to
increase 8.6 percent in fiscal 2009, with the city's share expected to rise by
$1.6 million.

"In order for us to continue to have good health benefits, we have to bring in
an affordable cost," Lothrop said.

"We need to explore this option."

Lothrop said there are "accommodations" within the GIC plan to pay for a
community's catastrophic health insurance claims.

A large number of catastrophic
claims caused Pittsfield's total health insurance costs to increase 18 percent
in fiscal 2007.

The committee also found that city employees who currently pay 20 percent of
their health insurance costs would realize annual savings of $451.44 on
individual plans, and $1,025.76 on family plans under the GIC.

The city, which
picks up 80 percent of its employees health insurance costs, would save
$1,805.76 annually on individual plans and $4,102.80 on family plans.

The GIC has 10 individual health insurance options as compared to four in the
city's plan, and some of the GIC's individual co-pays are higher than the
city's.

Ward 3 councilor and committee member Linda M. Tyer said that city employees
should determine which GIC option best suits their needs.

"Look at your own financial resources and health needs and decide which of the
plans works best for you and your family," she said.

To reach Tony Dobrowolski: TDobrowolski@berkshireeagle.com , (413) 496-6224

LOAD-DATE: May 7, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


   Copyright 2008 MediaNews Group, Inc. and New England Newspaper Group Inc.
                              All Rights Reserved

                                WMI Company News

                             July 15, 2014 Tuesday

Health Insurance Innovations acquires HealthPocket

LENGTH: 227 words


The acquirer believes that the takeover of HealthPocket will provide significant
competitive advantages, by merging HII's industry-leading health plan
development, virtual-administration and agent distribution of affordable health
insurance plans with HealthPocket's big-data-aggregation technology.

HealthPocket's technology, offers free, one-click access for consumers to review
on-and off-exchange individual major medical, Medicare, employer-sponsored and
ancillary health plans, ranked by price, by doctor or hospital provider, and
even by their personal prescription drug needs.

This information enables consumers to choose from the largest set of health
insurance plans and make informed health plan decisions.

Health Insurance Innovations CEO Mike Kosloske said, "The incorporation of
HealthPocket into Health Insurance Innovations fits with our growth strategy of
continued innovation of unrivaled products and technology solutions within the
insurance industry to further enhance our competitive advantage."

"This transaction will significantly increase leads, drive sales and enable us
to more swiftly expand into lucrative market adjacencies such as the $402B
Medicare marketplace, the $35B ACA segment of individual major medical and the
$220B employer-sponsored market, positioning the combined company for long-term
leadership in our dynamic industry."

                      August 22, 2017 Tuesday 6:30 AM EST

eHealth Works with Square to Help Small Businesses Find Health Insurance
Solutions

LENGTH: 294  words


Aug. 22 -- eHealth, Inc. (NASDAQ: EHTH), which operates eHealth.com, a leading
private online health insurance exchange, announced today that it is now
providing Square's small business customers with access to a broad range of
health insurance solutions as well as eHealth's innovative plan comparison tools
and robust customer support.

Square's point-of-sale service offers tools for every part of running a small
business, from accepting credit cards and tracking inventory to real-time
analytics and invoicing.

Through the Square dashboard, the more than two million
small businesses using Square now have access to a co-branded eHealth website
offering brand-name small business and individual & family health insurance
options.

By accessing eHealth through the Square dashboard, small businesses can compare
health insurance plans online from multiple insurance companies and get
customized quotes for their business.

At no cost, small business owners can also
get personalized help and useful advice from licensed eHealth agents.

eHealth
has also expanded its offering to enable online applications for small group
health insurance with select insurance companies, which enables health insurance
applications to be approved in as little as 24 hours in some instances.

"We are incredibly excited to work with Square and introduce their small
business customers to the great health insurance options available to them and
their employees," said eHealth CEO Scott Flanders.

"Whether they're purchasing
coverage only for themselves or for their employees as well, a quality health
insurance plan is an investment in any small business's future - and eHealth has
the comprehensive selection and tools they need to find the best plan for their
needs."

                        The Atlanta Journal-Constitution

                             May 21, 2009 Thursday
                                  Main Edition

Health care in spotlight;
Political heavyweights tackle issue of reform.

1B

LENGTH: 272 words


The prospect of a new government health insurance plan highlighted a debate on
health care reform in Atlanta on Wednesday, in which four political heavyweights
offered a preview of the debate expected on Capitol Hill.

The discussion --- held at the Georgia World Congress Center as part of a
biotech conference --- featured Karl Rove, former chief adviser to President
George W. Bush; Howard Dean, former chairman of the Democratic National
Committee; Republican Bill Frist, former U.S. Senate majority leader; and
Democrat Tom Daschle, also a former Senate majority leader.

* Karl Rove --- Rove attacked the prospect of a government-offered public health
insurance plan, saying, "A public plan is a government-run plan.

And a
government-run plan is bad."

Citing a poll, he also said many people are happy with their health coverage,
and don't want to see any new plan hurt that coverage.

* Howard Dean --- Dean favored a public health insurance plan, though stressed
he did not want to do away with the private sector.

"We need a public health insurance option to give people a choice," he said.

* Bill Frist --- Frist talked about the costs of implementing a government
health insurance program, saying, "Your taxes are going to go up."

Frist also expressed concerns that a government health care plan would stifle
innovation and competition.

* Tom Daschle --- He said the American people want to see Congress "get
something done" regarding health care.

"And they are very concerned about the
implications if we do nothing."

He said the public health care plan would address a major issue of Americans:
The need to lower health care costs.

committee chief; and ex-Senate majority leaders Bill Frist and Tom Daschle.

                               Irish Independent

                             June 4, 2014 Wednesday
                                   Edition 3;
                                National Edition

21,000 drop their health insurance in first three months of year

SECTION: NEWS; Pg.

15

LENGTH: 424 words


PRESSURE on the public hospital system is set to intensify after new figures
showed thousands more people have dropped their health insurance.

Close to 50,000 people ditched their private health insurance last year, a move
that will heap further pressure on Health Minister James Reilly.

This is because more people will be forced to use already under-pressure public
hospitals.

Only this week, the European Commission again questioned overspending on the
public health budget.

The new figures show that 47,000 stopped paying health insurance premiums in the
year up to March.

In the first three months of this year, 21,000 people dropped their inpatient
health insurance, according to new data from the Health Insurance Authority.

There are now just over two million people with inpatient cover, compared with
almost 2.3 million people when the market peaked at the end of 2008.

Rising premiums and the recession have been the main factors in people giving up
inpatient private health insurance.

Health insurance expert Dermot Goode predicted that the numbers with private
cover would drop below two million before the end of the year.

Mr Goode, of www.Healthinsurancesavings.ie, said the rate that people were
dropping health cover had slowed.

But he said that this was due to people dropping to cheaper plans and altering
the renewal date for their policies in a bid to keep premium costs down.

There have been a string of health insurance price rises this year alone, with
some plans soaring by as much as 41pc.

Some have responded by dropping their
cover, with others dropping down to cheaper plans.

In the latest move to ease the price pressure, the VHI said it would now extend
its half-price offer for children and students to all its hospital plans.

And insurers including Glo now allow families to design their own policies.

Benefits have also been reduced on plans.

With some plans, not every procedure
will be fully paid for, while excesses have been introduced across most plans.

This is the amount of a claim you pay yourself before the insurer picks up the
tab.

Last summer, Aviva stepped up this trend to limit what a health policy covers a
step further by launching its Focus plans that restrict the hospitals where it
will pay for procedures.

The plans were 20pc cheaper than similar policies.

Laya followed with no-frills
plans of its own, also with major restrictions.

Insurance experts predicted that we were now likely to see a family price war as
the companies scramble to sign up more customers.

LOAD-DATE: June 4, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Charlie Weston Personal Finance Editor
Dermot Goode: 'figures to fall'

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper
